The publishers liked my work, and when the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the project, they asked me to take his place. I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers, so I accepted. Things at home weren't going well, so a week in snowy Vienna sounded good to me.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy summer trip, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in cold January, it felt different. As soon as I arrived, I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. The first day, I just explored the city by tram, getting a feel for the place. The weather was cold and the city was full of grand old buildings. I hadn't seen Schussner's photos from other seasons because I wanted to capture my own version of Vienna.

A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. I spent time observing until I was ready. The next morning, I went out at dawn. Fresh snow had covered Stephansplatz, making it look untouched and almost empty. I wasn't sure how to photograph the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall like a giraffe's neck, but the base was large and heavy. I decided to focus on part of it, hoping to capture something magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even when you understand how it works. Watching a photo develop in a dark room is still mysterious. Maybe that's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**  
Something amazing has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, heavily advertised show, but rather a unique exploration of a nearly forgotten art form from the last 60 years. A new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the 20th century. It shows that creating art that moves or explores movement has been an ongoing, though often unnoticed, theme in some of the most interesting creative work of this century. Curator Guy Brett, who has studied this subject for a long time, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. These are displayed with little text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**  
David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative, making it easy to understand, or because it deals with themes of leisure and escape from everyday life. Some people might be more interested in Hockney's charming personality and clever words, which make him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is just an overrated minor artist. However, one could argue that he seems minor because being popular is not always accepted today, not because his work lacks depth. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to dismiss his work because it doesn't fit an abstract idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and knows that only time will tell his true place in art history.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**  
In recent years, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among certain artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. "Window-shopping" was a collection of individual artworks connected only by the fact that they were art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition but worked together through their contrasts. I didn't make any big statements about contemporary art, but maybe there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**  
People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it might ruin their experience. Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking at art and the act of creating it. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from enjoying the dish. Understanding something doesn't stop us from enjoying it; it might even enhance our pleasure. Enjoyment is complex, and how we perceive it can be questioned. Our preferences are influenced by societal values, not just our genes or personalities. While it's important to appreciate the sensory and instinctive responses to art, the idea that intellectual thought undermines sensory enjoyment is an outdated belief.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have first become interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow stone. It didn't feel like a regular stone, but it was beautiful. This is how gold might have become important to early humans. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became a popular material. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they started looking for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This is how metalworking became an important skill for our ancestors.

**St Ives**

We walked down the narrow, cobbled street into the town, carrying our bags. The wind was very strong, and we tried to avoid the cold waves crashing over the promenade. The streets were empty, and all the windows in the waterfront cottages were shut tight against the storm. We had seen the weather getting worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small train. The dark grey skies made us question our decision to visit Cornwall in the off-season without a car. I had convinced my friend to come with promises of beautiful coastal walks and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is difficult because it is gone. The people who lived through good and bad times are no longer here. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed communities are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We can't watch the past like a movie. However, computer modelling can help us recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital people have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for them and change conditions, like reducing rainfall or increasing population, to see how these virtual societies react.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth observed a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby. This stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean trouble for the current leader. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, the leader gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn about leopards. This scared the stranger back into the trees. The plan worked well until the leader made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while calmly walking in the open, revealing his trick.

**What Cats Catch**

In the English village of Felmersham, people collected the prey caught by their cats over a year. Seventy cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor estimated that, based on these numbers, cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this calculation is not accurate because most cats live in towns and catch fewer prey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes, as many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites. The survey showed that cats are significant predators but not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are very important to marsh people and are well cared for. Every morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping area slowly and with groans, heading to the reed beds. They stand at the edge, complaining about the day's work, until the leader finally moves into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and rest there for a while. Eventually, they start swimming, appearing tired and almost submerged, but they spend the day grazing among the reeds and bulrushes.

**PICASSO, Pablo - The Soles, 1940**

In early 1940, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and some soles. The fish and crab look alive, and the painting is hard to interpret because Picasso used overlapping and interlocking transparent shapes. The colors and brushwork create a calm, underwater feel. However, there is tension in the painting, as the fish and crab seem ready to fight. The sharp forms and even a chain around one fish add a sense of danger, giving the painting a symbolic meaning.

Photography has been around for about 150 years and has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this short time, photography has grown in its ability to capture moments in time and space, allowing us to see both big and small things. It has shown us images from faraway places on Earth, distant parts of the solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become a powerful way to express human experiences.

However, using images to record events is not new. The earliest examples of pictorial recording date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. We don't know exactly why early humans created cave paintings—whether they were recording real events, using them for magic to increase animals for hunting, as religious symbols, or simply to decorate their living spaces. But images have always been a part of human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and their importance in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has given visual images a special status. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it promised to provide a truthful visual record. The camera, working like the human eye, was seen as a tool that could capture a fixed image, very close to what we actually see. This was a big achievement because artists had spent centuries trying to create such realistic images.

Because photographs seemed so real, people thought everyone would naturally understand them, leading to the idea that photography could be a "universal language." For instance, in 1933, photographer August Sander said even isolated people could understand a photograph of the sky. But as global communication grew in the late 20th century, we began to question whether photography could truly cross cultural boundaries. Is photography as influenced by culture as language is? Have we become so used to photographs that we overlook the complex ways they convey reality?

Photography is often seen as providing clear evidence, making it seem like a transparent way to communicate. For example, when someone shows a photo from their wallet, saying "this is my grandson," it feels natural. Since its invention in 1839, photography and how people view it have changed a lot. Initially, it was a way to record events, but now photographs have become historical documents, revealing much about the people and societies that created them.

I aim to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not just reflect culture; it can also inspire social and political change. For example, the Italian Renaissance in the 15th century saw cultural changes partly due to new ways of visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a major role in creating the media culture of today, while also showing the harsh realities of the world in a way that is accessible to many.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching someone how to write poetry is tricky. It's like walking through a dangerous area: you need to be spontaneous, but one mistake can ruin everything. Claiming to know everything about poetry is risky, so instead, I suggest that beginners should read a lot, write often, and let their imagination and spirit be free, as long as it doesn't lead to chaos. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others can write even when they are unhappy. Some follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration. All methods are valid, as long as they are not just copying someone else's rules. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, there isn't space for too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to explain something important. A good way to do this is through a quick memory in the main character's mind, which can help move the story forward. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different sides of a situation quickly and keeps the reader interested. Writing too much can ruin a short story, but it doesn't mean it should be as short as a summary. Conflict and action should be strong, and every word should matter in the limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is similar to playing chess. Many chess players make moves without knowing the outcome, seeing only a few moves ahead. As they play more, they realize that chess is about long-term strategy, not just short-term tactics. They start to see the whole game and recognize patterns, like openings and end games. Similarly, the more you write screenplays, the more you understand their complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin once said that humans naturally speak, as seen in young children, but they don't naturally write. Language exists in all societies, and while languages change, they don't necessarily get better. All healthy children learn to speak without formal lessons. When children are together without a common language, they create one. Writing, however, has been invented only a few times in history, in complex societies, and has improved slowly over time. Until recently, many children didn't learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle. Children naturally learn to speak, but writing is a skill that must be taught carefully. We need to understand how writing works and how children's minds work to teach them effectively.

I have never started writing a novel with more doubt. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to call it. I don't have much of a story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader hanging. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up details to fill the gaps and make the story more complete, but I don't want to do that. I just want to share what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters made-up names and taken care to ensure no one recognizes them. The man I am writing about is not famous. He might never be. When he dies, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his strong, kind character will influence others, and people will realize he was remarkable. Then, it will be clear who I am writing about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limits, will be helpful to his future biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for things that matter to me. I have written these conversations in my own words, but I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I haven't invented anything, but I have taken the same liberty as historians to create speeches for people in my story that I didn't hear myself. I did this to make the scenes more lively and realistic. I want my book to be read, and I think it's fair to make it engaging. The smart reader will notice where I've used this technique and can choose to ignore it. Another reason I hesitated to write this book is that the people I write about are from a different culture. It's hard to truly know people, and I think you can only really know your own countrymen. People are shaped by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they enjoyed, and the poets they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't understand them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only know if you are them. Because you can't fully know people from another country just by observing, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I have only written about my own countrymen, and if I have written about others in short stories, it's because you can describe characters briefly in them. You give the reader a general idea and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I don't claim my characters see themselves as I describe them; they are seen through my eyes, just like the main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. It is only later that people can see clear patterns and recognize important works. Today, poetry is especially complex, with many different styles and opinions about how poetry should be written, presented, and understood. There is a general debate between two groups: serious 'literary' poets, who write poems to be read on paper, and 'popular' poets, who prefer performing their poems to an audience. However, this division is not strict.

Public poetry readings have become more common over the last twenty years. These events happen in various places, like small towns, schools, colleges, and arts festivals. Poets are often expected to perform their work publicly, which has mixed results for them. For 'pop' poets, who write specifically for live audiences, public performances are beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and easy to understand when heard once, but may seem less impressive when read on paper.

On the other hand, poets who focus on the craft of poetry, aiming to express deep emotions and thoughts in a concise and rhythmically complex way, may not be fully appreciated by audiences hearing their work for the first time. The risk is not that these poets will copy the style of entertainers, but that they might choose to read only their simpler works to connect quickly with the audience.

Listening to poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry on the page, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing poets read their work helps listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm intended by the poet. It is helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or is already familiar with the poems.

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to make poetry enjoyable and accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It's unrealistic to think that someone's spoken account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the person being interviewed influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to cover. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status compared to the interviewee and the historian's way of understanding history, which might affect the interviewee's responses. Historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. Even without the historian, the interviewee's memories might be influenced by other sources, like the media, or by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions in the testimony can seem convincing but might not be from the time being discussed.

**Animal Science**

Animal science can be studied in two main ways: focusing on the body's functions or looking at the whole animal. Physiologists study how the body's parts, like nerves and muscles, work together to create behavior. Those who study the whole animal look at the animal's behavior and what influences it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists usually work in labs, studying how animals like rats and pigeons learn. Ethologists study natural behaviors in animals, often in the wild. Although these fields are merging, physiologists often claim their methods are more basic. However, understanding every nerve cell's function doesn't eliminate the need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own structure that must be studied separately. Describing a bird's nest-building by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

Students new to social sciences face a challenge: they must learn both the content and the methods of the subject. They need to understand the knowledge and research in textbooks and the methods used to gather and organize this knowledge. These two parts are closely connected. Since we all experience social life daily, social sciences might seem like common sense. However, textbooks show that each social science goes beyond common sense. Each focuses on a specific part of social life, uses specific study methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts form the 'logical basis' of the subject, helping social scientists go beyond everyday understanding and distinguishing one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek terms for some of these ideas, likely from an earlier Greek source. Utility and function are not part of his definition, though he later discusses the best designs for different purposes. Initially, the focus is on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins. Before Vitruvius' time, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy that didn't meet his artistic standards. Despite being simple, these early structures contributed to later architectural ideas. No matter how elaborate it looks, a classical temple is essentially a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. She would finish her drive near the gasworks, surrounded by the smell of sulphur. Surprisingly, Chen found out and was amused by Lily's secret driving. He praised her, saying, "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought men were strange because Chen should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of the next month, as it was the quietest day for their business. They planned to leave early and return by midday to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. However, Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

On the day of the trip, they left the house and, within an hour, were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit it. Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, and Chen even applauded her. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a street with many empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings, so she decided to pay for parking to avoid any trouble. Lily locked all the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don't worry, no one will want that heap of tin," which annoyed the sisters. Lily accused him of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for judging by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He held Man Kee on the railing and thought about his son's future. Chen wanted Man Kee to have a good education and own many restaurants one day.

The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful. He saw a ship on the horizon and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it clearly—a small, old, rusty ship. Chen lifted Man Kee to the telescope and said, "Do you see the ship, Son? It's special for people like us. It will take us back home when we're done here." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them, and Chen let Lily look through the telescope. However, by then, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, and all Lily could see were seagulls following the ship's path.

**THE WELL**

I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't think about how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle as I pushed the bucket off the well's edge, but I fell immediately. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn't realize I had sort of succeeded in my plan. I saw strange lights, like the stars and planets you see in cartoons when a character gets hit on the head. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I was about to shout back when you called again, sounding more panicked, which stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I could hear worried voices from the castle. Mother and Father came out with you and old Arthur. Mother was shouting and waving her hands. Father told Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I hid in the shadows, feeling a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to where I was hiding. I was horrified that no one had seen them. Father was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops shone in the sunlight. I couldn't believe no one noticed them. Mother was screaming, a sound I had never heard before. It made me feel guilty. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. It had gone from a clever idea to a big problem that wouldn't go away without someone, probably me, getting in trouble. I regretted not thinking it through. From a smart plan to a disaster in just a few minutes. Then I had an idea. I gathered my courage and came out of hiding, pretending to be weak and dizzy. I called out softly, then louder when no one heard me. I stumbled forward and collapsed dramatically. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I pretended to be relieved and said I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat. I claimed I crawled and swam through it to escape. I thought I was convincing them until Father asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated, and his eyes narrowed. Trying to cover up, I said the tunnel collapsed after me, so there was no point in checking it. I said the well was dangerous and I barely escaped. I looked into my father's eyes, and it felt like looking into a dark tunnel with no stars. It was like he saw me for the first time, and I realized how my story must sound to an adult. My words stopped. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, with more contempt than I thought possible. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked at me, his face sad and worried, not because I had a scary adventure and wasn't believed, but because he saw through my lie and was concerned about my character. His pity was as painful as my father's words, showing that this was the adult judgment of my actions, not something I could ignore. It affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, a widow, is moving out of her family home now that her children are grown up. The moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it, and Susan noticed that everything special about the house was being packed away. Fred, the removal man, was carefully wrapping fragile items, while his team was not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that overlooked a small harbor. Memories of her children growing up there lingered in the air like dust.

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked how they would bring the house home. Now, Robert was there to help with the move, making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Her daughter Francesca was also helping, insisting that only she could handle the Steinway piano with enough care.

Fred, the removal man, commented that Susan didn't seem like she was going to cry. He explained that many people cry when they see their home being taken apart, but they feel better once they reach the new place. Susan could understand this feeling. **Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

Is do-it-yourself literary criticism just harmless fun? From the beginning, the idea of open access to the Internet was a key principle. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or start a music channel online. In reality, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that truly opened up to everyone was literary criticism. With Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could write book reviews. Amazon's approach allowed anyone to share their opinion on a book and rate it up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because it let potential buyers see what other readers thought, not just the publisher's description or professional critics' opinions.

Other online bookstores, which also had physical stores, offered similar features. But Amazon, being the largest with over 80% of the online market, attracted the most reviews and, therefore, faced the most issues. This open review system led to some problems. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily, and it was impossible to check them all. Amazon had a team of editors to ensure reviews followed their guidelines. Reviews with just one word, personal attacks, or spoilers were not allowed. However, reviewers were anonymous, and inappropriate reviews were only removed if noticed by Amazon's team.

This anonymity allowed for some mischief. For example, authors could write positive reviews of their own books. Lev Grossman, an author, wrote fake positive reviews for his book after receiving negative ones. His trick worked until he admitted it in an article, and the fake reviews were removed. Authors could also comment on their books through a special link, but Amazon did not verify if the comments were truly from the authors, except for famous writers. A fake comment pretending to be from John Updike was removed because it was clearly not from him.

Most controversies came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book "We've Got Spirit" was published, it was praised by the mainstream press. However, people mentioned in the book felt betrayed and used Amazon's review section to express their anger. Many critical reviews appeared but were later removed. Despite such incidents, Amazon saw the high number of reviews as good for business. Reviews were meant to be a place to discuss books, not a chat room, so Amazon closely monitored bestselling books to ensure reviews followed the rules. Silly reviews were more likely to be found on less popular books. For example, a children's book called "The Story about Ping" inspired humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in Internet technology.

Overall, most Amazon reviews were serious and provided a good indication of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books meant inventing feelings about books one didn't care about. This makes the democratization of book reviews a positive development.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, people have started to think that every artist must go against the art of their time. Art is often praised for being unique, revolutionary, or even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to modern art, we often hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, claiming it is no longer art. The media often express these thoughts for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in contemporary art. We want artists to be different from the rest of us, with special talents and energy that cannot be contained by conventions. In the past, people would commission artists for specific purposes, making art a part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to their own ideas and get annoyed if they try to be more relatable.

Here's the situation: An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. Then, he asks a sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas, instructing them not to make the lettering flashy or charming. **Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to the past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, like knowing about our grandparents and their lives. But beyond that, there is a need to learn about our past to understand our future, both individually and as a nation. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel secure about the future by understanding the past. Just like we inherit genes, we also inherit culture passed down through generations. There might be parts of our national heritage we don't like, but it is still part of us, and it feels good to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. In the past, we connected with our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, Western industrial society broke up communities, and much of this oral tradition has been lost. Now, places and buildings help us learn about our past. It is crucial to preserve these links to honor our ancestors' identity.

**The Fens**

I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became important. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I thought the Fens were a quiet, empty place to set my story. But I learned that the Fens are not flat or empty. They are as English as any other part of England but also strangely unique. It's surprising that in the middle of England, there is a place that feels foreign to many English people, even though other unique areas of Britain have become part of the nation's cultural heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, open and mysterious. While writing my novel, I didn't visit many places in the Fens. I haven't been to Wisbech or Prickwillow yet. As a fiction writer, I like to imagine worlds and prefer to make inspired guesses rather than rely on facts. Imagining the Fens makes sense because, as Edward Storey's book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility means more. Displays should be lively and interesting, using techniques to capture visitors' attention and emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artifacts and specimens, not replicas. They offer encounters with authentic items that existed and had meaning in history. This is their strength and what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and offer exciting displays, catalogs, and outreach programs will find that virtual history can actually help them by increasing interest in the real items that only museums can provide.

**Language**  
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mysterious origin has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller claimed that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad. Humans in dangerous lands with scary animals made desperate sounds, and languages have kept some of these sounds, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death". Because of such odd ideas, many people avoided the topic, thinking it was for eccentric thinkers. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, unlike what philosopher John Locke thought when he described language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode looks at the skill of writing reviews from a writer's perspective. Most reviews are written quickly and have a short lifespan. They have deadlines and strict word limits. Once published, they last only as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear in, which could be a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this short life, reviews are often not seen as important literature. Many people, including the writers, think reviewing is a job done for extra money or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a complex and skilled job. Writing a short, fair review of 600-800 words for a newspaper is different from writing a detailed 6,000-8,000 word review for an international journal. A 1,500-word review in a weekly magazine has challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, from casual readers to those deeply interested in the subject. Reviewers need to know a lot about many topics and write clearly and engagingly. This means reviewers often write other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who doesn't think highly of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews between his novels. He collects all his reviews, even short ones, into books with modest titles. Some might think less famous writers should accept that their reviews are temporary, but if they can, they should enjoy some recognition, especially if they believe their best work is in reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike other cultures, it's common for the same people to write both reviews and academic studies. In the past, academics criticized professors who wrote reviews for showing off or wasting time, but now it's more accepted. Complaints from non-professors that professors are taking their jobs are also less common, partly because there are more reviews to write and partly because the pay is often low. I believe this is good for readers, who can trust the reviewer knows the subject, and for professors, as it helps them stay connected to a wider audience. It reminds them to communicate clearly with non-professors. While they might use complex language with each other, they need to be clear when writing for a general audience. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and entered the dark, still hallway. Even after three years, he sometimes felt a brief doubt about owning the place when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, wondering what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or the answering machine would be blinking with messages. He was thankful that the windows hadn't been broken or the flat damaged, but he wondered what it would look like if it had been. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to spending three or four evenings alone at home each week. Once he left the artificial world of the office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he realized he didn't need to be alone, a fact he often forgot when planning his social life. At his desk, he longed for time alone with his belongings, but once he got home, he felt empty and waited in vain for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him think that doing work he didn't like had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would often read or listen to music at night, but now he questioned why he did these things. His sense of direction was unclear, and his thoughts and feelings seemed to get lost in his mind. He remembered a time when he didn't feel so powerless, when he might have escaped if he had realized his own value. But he had been eager to settle into something and followed the first opportunity that came along. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he found he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without imagining he could find happiness in his work. He went to his only job interview with gratitude and didn't think to evaluate the job—a vague editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would face daily. Neil offered him the job on the spot, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush making mayonnaise by adding oil too quickly, it will curdle. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take longer—seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some mental tasks can be sped up, like solving crossword puzzles or doing mental math faster. But other tasks cannot be rushed, or they will fail, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line. Saying "Think fast; we need the results" can be as silly as trying to sleep for only half the night. We learn, think, and understand in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds and are suited for different tasks. "He who hesitates is lost," says one proverb. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. Generally, the mind has three different speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate, instinctive reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road in London, my brain and body quickly reacted to keep me safe, and only afterward did my conscious mind catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer doesn't have time to think about their next move. This fast physical intelligence is often called our "wits." Then there is thought itself: the kind of intelligence that involves figuring things out, weighing pros and cons, building arguments, and solving problems. A mechanic figuring out why an engine won't start, a scientist interpreting an experiment, or a student working on an assignment all use this type of intelligence, which relies on reason and logic. We often call this "intellect." People who are good at this are called "bright" or "clever." Below this is another, slower mental process. It is often less focused and more relaxed or dreamy. In this mode, we are thinking things over, being contemplative or meditative. Sitting by the sea, lost in the sound of the waves, or just before sleep, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind time to wander is not a luxury to cut back on when life gets busy. In fact, slow thinking is an important part of our mental abilities. We need the slow mind as much as the fast one. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some mysteries can only be understood with a relaxed, open mental attitude. Recent studies show that slower, less deliberate thinking is good for understanding complex or unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well when the problem is clear. When deciding where to go on holiday, the options might be obvious. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to ask, or when the issue is too subtle for conscious thought, we need the slow mind. If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work or whether to change careers, it might be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and even "wisdom." Poets have long known the limits of conscious thinking and have tried to develop these slower ways of knowing. Philosophers have written about the parts of the mind beyond conscious thought. Only recently have scientists started to study these slower ways of knowing. The field of "cognitive science" is showing that the unconscious mind can do many interesting and important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns too subtle for normal consciousness, understand complex situations, and solve difficult issues better than the conscious mind.

**Lake Vostok**

In the center of Antarctica, everything is still. While there are many penguins, seals, and birds on the edges of the continent, the vast white interior is lifeless. This water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths to find out what unusual organisms might live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For the past two years, researchers from around the world have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If they succeed, the next few years could be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that a group of scientists is debating what motivates them to become scientists. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the timeless quest for knowledge and the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we have this desire in the first place and why science can't explain it. Surely, it's more important to consider whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. I believe the key issue is not why we pursue science, but to recognize that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**

Our connection with food is very basic and fulfilling. Many people who love cooking buy cookbooks like this one. Often, we think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complex dishes. But that's not true. You can make a delicious soup just by putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and a few herbs into water. This is much more satisfying than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with too much sugar and preservatives, you can make a delicious dessert in five minutes that both adults and children will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by bringing your own creation, no matter how simple, to the table. Sharing food is full of meaning and meets our deep human needs, which is why all our celebrations, like birthdays, anniversaries, and engagements, happen around tables. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party! And not many people would want to discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to tidy up his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from desk drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing them. He also had extra paperwork from owning an apartment building. Books and journals were near the new bookshelves but not organized. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on time. She was very precise about time and neatness. How would she react to the mess? She might think someone had vandalized the place. He could pretend to be shocked when he walked in behind her. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her hopefully as she unlocked his apartment door. Her eyes showed she wasn't going to help with the office mess. She believed he was like a visitor from another world, not part of her familiar Brooklyn streets.

**KAREN**

Karen wanted to be different from her mother, which led her to create her own story of strength. In her story, there were important moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she was blind, but the doctor assured her that the bone had protected her eye. She only needed a few stitches, which healed as a reminder of past pain. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles and small mercies, she felt she was saved for a purpose.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty was walking quickly across the village green, feeling both excited and sad about what she had just seen. In a small community, it's exciting to be the first to know something important, and her quiet life didn't have much excitement. But she was very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years, and she appreciated his care for her yearly throat infections, which were her only health issues. His best quality was making patients feel he had plenty of time for them and truly wanted to hear their worries. This quality made him very loved by the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received loyalty and affection.

**Joanna's Lessons**

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. Despite her hectic schedule, she has started writing books for young children learning the piano. Joanna's performances are exciting, and even people who don't know much about music can enjoy them. She plays many different styles, like classical, jazz, and blues, and even does fun tricks like plucking the piano strings. At a recent concert for children, a boy asked her to play the theme from "Match of the Day," a popular TV show. Joanna found this amusing and played it, proving to the boy that she was a "proper pianist."

Joanna is unique among top pianists because she cares about how young children learn to play the piano. She has published a beginner's piano book for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World," even though she is very busy. This summer, she is involved in many music festivals and projects, and she also runs her own recording label, Sound Circus. People are surprised she took on the extra work of writing a book, but she believes the first lessons in music are very important. She thinks music should be accessible to everyone, not just those with exceptional talent.

Joanna's experience with teaching beginners and growing up in a home where her mother taught piano has influenced her. She believes everyone should have the chance to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French. Some children learn quickly, but she is interested in those who progress at different rates and sometimes give up. She worries that some parents push their children too hard to achieve in music, rather than letting them enjoy it.

Joanna's books are colorful and engaging, with storylines and CDs to make learning fun. She believes learning should be enjoyable and encourages children to improvise and explore the piano. As children progress, they need to learn to read music, which can be challenging. Joanna understands this because she relied on her ear when she was young. However, she believes practice is the most important part of learning. She didn't practice seriously until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she learned to love it. Now, she practices eight hours a day, which she considers the core of her musical life. She advises setting clear goals for practice, rewarding yourself, and mixing difficult pieces with easier ones.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson once said that writing without effort is usually not enjoyable to read. This suggests that good writing is difficult to achieve. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice there were very few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was physically hard, which made me think more carefully. Since it was hard to change or erase, I wrote with more care. On the other hand, using a computer can make us careless. Many writers find that they spend as much time fixing drafts on a computer as they did writing by hand. Similarly, emails, unlike handwritten letters, can be emotionally heavy. Some say emails have brought back the art of love letters, with millions being sent instead of just casual talk. That's a good thing. At least these emails are written in some form of English and grammar. However, words on a screen can feel dull. Writers often don't realize the power of written words and may exaggerate their meaning. Words typed quickly lack the care and personality of handwriting.

**The CD**

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not impressive, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Aren't they amazing?" Mr. Warriston said as he returned to the room. I agreed and carefully handed the disc to him. "It's incredible they can hold seventy minutes of music," he said, as he turned on the hi-fi system. Lights came on, and he pressed a button to open a small drawer. He placed the disc inside and closed it. "Some people say they sound too clean, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston replied, surprised. "No, you only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked puzzled, then thoughtful. "You know," he said, "I have no idea. I don't see why you couldn't use both sides and double the capacity..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers, or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He gestured to my chair. "Anyway, let's get you sitting in the best spot for the stereo sound, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.

**Books versus Electronic Text**

When comparing books and electronic text, author Malcolm Bradbury was right when he said that if matches were invented after lighters, we'd be amazed by the improvement. Many people, excited by new technology, claim that electronic text is as revolutionary as the invention of printing and that this change is almost complete. They forget that changes in how we think take a long time, and such claims are often self-centered, thinking their generation is at a historical turning point. For example, a book from 1979 predicted that books would start disappearing in the 1980s. This prediction was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is often unpleasant, so most people don't do it. Also, the way information is organized on computers encourages people to read only small parts. Some technology enthusiasts argue that this leads to new ways of storytelling, but there's nothing new about reading non-linearly. Many books, like religious texts, dictionaries, and poetry collections, are not read from start to finish. What's new is that computers don't encourage reading a whole text in one go.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office and saw a perfectly organized space. The carpet was free of the papers that had covered it since it was installed, and the desk was the dark wood he remembered from an auction five weeks ago. Neat file-holders were being placed in drawers. Twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves on one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You need to switch to computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, admiring the room and its antique furniture. He wasn't thinking about adding a computer or any other device, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had this conversation many times. She couldn't understand why he resisted technology when he was so skilled with computers and had even published an important paper on computer-related talents. She had inspired that paper. With a keyboard, she could transform any software into something new and exciting.

Lancelot's secretary shouted, "You don't take sugar, do you?" She wasn't really asking because she had been making him coffee for months. She often forgot things because he wasn't supposed to be there. However, he was there all the time now because staying away would cause chaos. He thought about how he had gone from being a respected advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to a stressed worker with no parking space at work.

His secretary handed him a folder, saying it was from someone in Los Angeles. The label read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert" and "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot didn't want to see another synopsis; he wanted a first draft. Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, but commissioning books from friends had been a mistake. Ian was unpredictable and unreliable.

Lancelot skimmed the synopsis, recognizing almost every phrase. He realized Ian's manuscript might never come. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and seemed to lack conviction. Lancelot remembered a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death, with payments made chapter by chapter. But Ian had already received a large advance, which went against the usual business practice of paying authors after they deliver a manuscript.

Lancelot recalled when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge, where his peers took over British theatre. Ian was even more talented but never fulfilled his potential. He was difficult to work with, even when appointed to edit an arts magazine, which never published despite using up its budget. His contract with a fashion magazine produced little except stories about his high salary, which increased in hopes of making him produce more.

At editorial meetings, Ian was critical and sarcastic, but ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to admit that commissioning "A World History of the Short" had been a mistake from the beginning.

Text: 'The breakfast change in England

Health experts agree that having a good breakfast is very important. However, breakfast is a relatively new habit in England. In medieval times, breakfast was rarely mentioned in literature. There are a few mentions of travelers eating at dawn before long journeys and sick people having breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. In the sixteenth century, breakfast slowly became common for everyone. Some people think this happened because there was more food available. However, they might not have considered other important social changes. For example, new work patterns could explain why breakfast became more important. People started working set hours, often very early in the morning. So, eating a meal in the morning became necessary and was no longer just for the wealthy.'

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to include based on their skills, personal views, and experiences, along with social and cultural norms. In this book, we will explore how these factors influence the style, content, and expression of a photograph, and how viewers perceive and react to these images. For instance, a newspaper reader might understand the photos they see, but instead of just accepting them, we might ask if the photo truly shows what the scene looked like at that moment. Or, does it show the photographer's perspective? Is the exact moment captured important, or should the photo be seen as a symbol of a situation in the world?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport has always been more than just a game. The most successful athletes have complete self-confidence. You need to focus entirely if you want to succeed in sports. There's only one way to be the best, and you have to prioritize it above everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's a matter of survival. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but it also shows the value of teamwork. My sport allows you to shine individually, but it's also a team game, and you need to balance both. It's similar to life - you can succeed alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot - not just money. It has opened opportunities for me and shown me things around the world that others might never see. But you also have to sacrifice a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences are so vivid that they stand out clearly in our memories. For me, one such moment happened one night in California years ago. I was lying awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from somewhere in the tall trees around the neighborhood. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing singing kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt like I was in a new artistic world. To follow the bird's patterns, I thought of my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an incredible, spontaneous musical performance. I reacted with amazement as each surprising musical variation came through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

Birds have always been important in human culture. They are loved, feared, and even worshipped. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 

In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is bumping against the glass. Wrens are seen as mysterious birds, linked to predictions and messages. Is this wren trying to tell us something, or is it just trapped? Both ideas could be true, depending on how you see it. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, wrens are still popular in British art and homes. Even if old beliefs have faded, wrens still hold a special place in our hearts. A forest without wrens feels empty and sad.

This connection to birds comes from a long history of folklore. In the past, people depended on nature for survival and developed a way to understand the world through the behavior of animals. This understanding changes over time. For example, in the 1500s, red kites were common in London and were seen as helpful scavengers. Later, they were considered pests and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain.

Our relationship with birds goes back to early human history. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn of danger, bad weather, or food sources. Birds also connected people to their dreams and the supernatural. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and envy. Some might say these feelings are outdated, but they are still part of us, like the appendix or wisdom teeth. Losing them would be painful.

Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is sad not only because we lose these birds but also because we lose part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have deep cultural meanings, representing love and magic. Their loss is felt deeply by those who know their significance in literature and folklore. However, birds without cultural stories are often ignored when they disappear.

Folklore is important because it keeps the connection to birds alive in a way that scientific terms cannot. Stories, legends, and rhymes about birds have a strong bond with their subjects and evoke feelings and attitudes that science cannot capture. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to explain scientifically. Birds engage us in ways we don't fully understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages.

The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and a distant past, holding a mystery in its song and flying into the future, leaving us to wonder.

Maps are used to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in terms of time, like "a day's journey by river," which told more about how easy it was to travel through an area than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, knowing "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" was more crucial than precise directions. Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, sometimes more so than maps. Even today, some maps, like those of railway systems, might not show true directions accurately. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of these signs depended on the map's purpose and where it was made, so understanding early maps requires knowing the specific style used.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and making maps more detailed. Cartography has used other sciences to help with this. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people started using the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that the earth is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.

Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps for military purposes, especially after the introduction of artillery, which required understanding the landscape in detail. This led to the invention of contour lines to show elevation. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work. Today's map makers, or cartographers, have developed ways to map various things, like geological layers, climate, and land use. The recognition of maps' value in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.

However, the development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid change, with old ideas sometimes existing alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what needed to be done but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since making a map by copying an old one is easy, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers have sometimes been slow to adopt new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken as perfect evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them a valuable record for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and educational.

I was invited into a young man's living room, which felt like a calm and cultured space compared to the messy rooms around it where his less ambitious family members spent their time. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. In this room, I saw the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and surprisingly, a teenager who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't a matter of life or death, although it's easy to say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy goal for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was open to trying it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' record collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and showing him a seven-inch single of a song I had written, which an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to make a big impact in musical theatre, probably very soon. And even if we didn't succeed in challenging the top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, the brief certainty I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would, of course, keep looking at the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and would write a few more simple songs that didn't show the limits of my voice, but it was still likely that I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would surely have outgrown pop music, as my father confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and to write lyrics that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. Andrew was a fascinating person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't really inspire me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, borrowing too much from Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title as well, most of which had probably been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Language**

Humans have an amazing ability: we can communicate with each other in a very precise way. Language is so important to us that it's hard to imagine life without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to speak naturally, just like spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a special spider teacher, and they don't need to be good at building to do it.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather, which are mainly created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can change the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Daily weather patterns, which together make up the climate, are caused by large masses of air moving and mixing because the atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement happens because the air is on a spinning Earth, and it doesn't move as fast as the planet. The sun is an even more important cause of air movement.

**Coffee**

As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks, but I was more worried about making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, including how to clean and maintain the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key steps to making a perfect cup of rich, frothy cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might be sent back to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to get good at it."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often fail to make good programs about visual arts like painting and sculpture? These art forms should be perfect for TV because cameras can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see details. However, there are few TV series that successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which is about American art. Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I thought the series would focus on great artworks, but instead, it was more about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known for taking risks. The metals market is less regulated than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a normal part of the industry, and it fits well with a free-market global economy. However, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the prices of scarce metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your room doesn't come with one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis available. You can also rent a boat if you want to travel on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, naturally protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Title: Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK

At the Bamboo Bike Club in Hackney Wick, east London, you can join a weekend course to build your own custom bamboo bike frame. The club is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. On a Saturday morning, the sound of machinery fills the air as participants start their bike-building journey. The atmosphere is lively and fun, unlike any typical woodwork class.

Bamboo is becoming popular in bike construction, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire leading the way. However, their ready-made bamboo frames are expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable, so they spent years developing a product that average cyclists could afford. They realized they wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable, not just sell frames.

The Bamboo Bike Club is more of a community project than a business. James and Ian run it alongside their full-time jobs—James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. Their courses are popular because they offer a custom-designed bike frame and a fun weekend experience at a competitive price.

For someone like me, who isn't great at DIY, the quality of the bike was a concern. On the first day, James and Ian teach how to choose strong bamboo and form solid joints. The process involves gluing bamboo tubes together to form the bike's frame. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks.
