Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans earned him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success story.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. His year began poorly when a film project called *Life and Limb*, which he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't made any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to keep his bank manager happy. A sensible person in Evans' situation might have found a job. He could have returned to being a TV executive or started a TV project he had paused. Instead, he made a risky decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.

Although this decision was impulsive, the idea for the story had been with him for a while. It started when he met a farrier on Dartmoor who told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These men were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated and began researching the topic to write a screenplay. But after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was watching people, but I felt alone and like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By August, he had returned home and written half of the book. The bank manager was pressuring him, and he needed to know if it was worth continuing. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and guessed Evans might get $30,000 as an advance. Evans needed more than that to pay off some debt and support his family. He had spent seven months on the book and needed at least two more. $30,000 was not enough. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, the first 200 pages and the summary were sent to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just sense something is happening.'"

What happened next was remarkable. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

The studios agreed to pay this amount, and they each presented their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four top filmmakers called, one after the other, to ask for the chance to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel.

Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on the verandah of his home. He said he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been such a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is tough, and I don't want to become an employee of people I like and who have paid me so much. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He would be involved, but from a distance. The success of his novel also brought new support for *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is trying to make a comeback in the world of chess, but age is not on his side. Chess has become a game for younger players. After 20 years away from the game, Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a brilliant move, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, he is 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older.

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer himself helped make chess more popular, leading to a new era of professional chess. Now, the focus is on winning, and players need strong nerves and stamina, as well as intelligence. The pressure in chess is very high. Players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose the game. Games are longer now, and many are played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Among the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30.

The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board, with players preparing extensively before matches. Computers have had a big impact on chess. A small computer can store a million chess games and help players study their opponents. In some matches, players have teams working to find weaknesses in their opponent's strategies. The opening moves of a game are now studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can decide the outcome.

Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money around the world. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused the whole time. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension, especially during the final moments of the game when players have only seconds to make their moves. This is a time of intense pressure, where nerves and determination are key.

At the highest level, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and relief. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready to compete every day, as most tournaments last 9-11 days. There is a year-round tournament circuit, and world championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10kg during the match.

Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long break from chess after 1972 hard to understand, but it also made him a legend. If Fischer has returned for the money, he will earn a lot. But if he truly believes he can still be the best, the result could be disappointing.

**Fame and Fortune: Interviews with Rising British Talent**

**A. Nick Grosso**  
Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, is a playwright with three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a film script. "It's a low-budget project, but we're not sure how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Interestingly, before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he admits. "It's set in a car, which I wouldn't do now because of the challenges. I knew nothing back then." Nick left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "Being around like-minded people was the first time I enjoyed an educational environment. It was very inspiring."

**B. Simon Pegg**  
Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has progressed significantly since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and recently completed a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard, even performing in comedy clubs during his university days. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his collaboration with Steve Coogan has been the most rewarding. "Steve saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed me imitating him," Simon admits.

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**  
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show received great reviews, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was destined for success. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse to avoid homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I realized I wanted to pursue it because I was good at it and loved it." Now, he is waiting for more recognition but is thoughtful about fame. "At 18, you think you'll love the attention, but you soon realize it's not why you act. It's about earning respect for good work."

**D. Neil Taylor**  
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to become very popular when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company has high expectations, but I don't know what to expect. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was performing at student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times I was very discouraged, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**  
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known on the poetry circuit, where he has been performing for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that couldn't be a poem," he says. Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with a theater job, I decided to go." After university, he published a children's book in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because I read a lot as a child." With his poetry being praised, moving to novels is a bold step. "Poetry has a structure, so there's less chance of making mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for errors. My main goal is to avoid producing work without caring about its quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this fun and quirky novel, is an art student who loves historical romance stories. She is 31 years old and is looking for the perfect partner, Mr. Right. However, she worries that her bony knees might ruin her chances. Despite this, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.'

B. This story is about the beginning and near-end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old Ford cars, and the radio.

C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. So, when successful professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he naturally shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she also wants his help for her brother, who is in prison unfairly. However, the most interesting part is how the author solves these problems. The story is funny and smart, making it a very enjoyable read.

D. Two pairs of best friends, two women and two men, meet in London during the 1960s and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of the four, an American businessman named James Hudson, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one of them married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is excellent. This book is long and detailed, allowing readers to really get to know the characters.

E. This story, written by a top American fiction writer, is both funny and touching. It tells how Ian Bedloe, feeling guilty for a mistake, becomes the 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is slowly becoming an odd bachelor surrounded by the mess of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the sweet relationship Ian builds with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and lovely book with a perfect mix of sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism: Perspectives from Four Academic Writers**

**A.** The direct impact of volunteer tourism on development is often questioned. Volunteer tourists might help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a large fee to participate. This money, if given directly to local communities, could hire more workers than a single volunteer could replace. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack technical skills or professional experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in gaining experiences that will benefit their careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and considerate of less fortunate people in their future careers and lives.

**B.** Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and more participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also create international social networks among ordinary people. In this way, the benefits for both volunteers and host communities can contribute to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by people from wealthier areas, it might only give these privileged individuals a broader perspective and career advantages, without significantly helping the communities they visit. These volunteers might use the experience to advance personally, rather than truly benefiting the host communities.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity by wealthy Westerners. It can also be a straightforward way to provide technical help for development. At its best, it benefits both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for an exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to fighting inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism aligns with the trend of wanting to help others through personal actions. These efforts, aimed at making a small difference, can seem positive in a world that often distrusts politics. The personal approach avoids big government and business, but it also skips the democratic process and reduces development to individual charity acts. While volunteering is a commendable act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can degrade the true meaning of development. The politics of volunteer tourism can shift focus away from understanding global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help us get out of bed. That's where the clock radio comes in. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, which included me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

The first model has a 'dual alarm function,' but it doesn't work as expected. You can't use it to snooze and then wake up again. Instead, it's meant for setting two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and another for weekends. However, not everyone needs this feature. This model is priced similarly to the second one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a nice bonus. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was excellent, but the device is quite large, about the size of a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone, so he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was the most attractive and was our overall favorite. Paul Bridges said he 'fell in love with it,' although the clock on his test model kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which was a problem when I finally looked at the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a self-power backup, so you don't have to reset it if someone unplugs it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner. We all liked this feature, but setting it up was complicated, though we felt 'cool' and sophisticated once we figured it out.

Tom Granger thought the model with an extra built-in lamp was 'unbelievably tacky.' You have to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which made him question the quality. He had to read the instructions twice to get it working, as the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light is hard to position and only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer is loud and reminded me of a submarine alarm, making me want to throw it across the room. Despite this, it's the third most popular model on the market.

Aimed at young people, this model has a bright casing and a matching strap, which appealed to Tom Granger and me. 'I would choose this one because it stands out,' he said. The traditional controls made it the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, either early or late. Paul Bridges found this unacceptable and called the model 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it was 'standard and took up little space.' It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found more intuitive. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed the buttons correctly, so you can't trust it to work. He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was basic, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model was effective; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal known for the sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not originally from America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened, making their spines stick out to protect them. This defense works well if the hedgehog has many spines. Some hedgehogs that live in deserts have fewer spines because they have adapted to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have no other choice.

Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in sports is challenging for everyone, but women often face extra difficulties. They have to train hard and make sacrifices, leaving little time for a normal life. Despite these challenges, many women are overcoming obstacles and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

"I love the feeling of flying through the air and landing smoothly, but it can be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but you just have to keep going. It's hard to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You miss out on social life and friends, but it's my choice. In the British team, there are six men and three women. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally—it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won because I was the fastest, even though I had never cycled before! As a professional, I'm well paid, and there are opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry people might think I succeed because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling now, rather than making money. I train at least four hours a day, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the time commitment."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

"Rowing is hard for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. Most start at 19 or 20, making it tough to succeed internationally. Coaches often stay for only a year, so there's no consistency, and the women's squad is disorganized. But it's fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how big it was! Britain felt too small and safe. I was stubborn and disliked being controlled. Now, I'm more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the most painful experience—50 miles and 21 hours a day with only three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, as my sponsorship money was running out. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as risky."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

"Some men have big egos when driving—you see it on motorways. When I do well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its downsides. At corners, men think, 'I have to beat her,' so I've had many collisions! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It's hard to earn money, and what I make goes back into racing. Women have raced since the 1920s and were seen as eccentric. It's great that more women are racing now. I love aiming for perfection and trying to complete a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

"I wake up at 5:30 a.m. three times a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There's a lot of nervous energy before a race, and you push yourself hard. I've often asked why I do it. The reasons are: a) I'm happier when fit, b) I'm naturally lazy and need to push myself, c) racing is social. Men and women usually compete together, but media coverage focuses mostly on men. Prize money isn't as good for women, but we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission to work on this."

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was an 18-year-old student. He was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. While in Cannes, he ran out of money and got a job painting boats. One day, he saw Picasso having lunch at a restaurant in the harbor. Picasso was a famous artist who usually kept to himself, so Richard was surprised to see him there with his wife and friends.

Encouraged by a friend, Richard approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and even added a drawing to the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, using an American woman at the table as an interpreter because Picasso's English was not good.

After showing the autograph to his friend, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, he started sketching Picasso, who playfully made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard. Eventually, Picasso stopped moving and allowed Richard to draw him properly. Richard noticed how youthful and intense Picasso's eyes were, despite his age.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the drawing. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and then added his own quick drawing to the page. He humorously altered Richard's portrait, making it look like a character from one of his playful artworks. Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature.

Looking back, Richard feels lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It was a memorable experience for him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here, we explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. To highlight this, they often place fruits, vegetables, or house plants at the store entrance. They might also have an in-store bakery, so the smell of fresh bread fills the air. The store's colors, like green, can also make things seem fresher. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't fit this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

Where products are placed in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With technology, supermarkets know which areas customers visit most. They place high-profit or fast-selling items there. Products at eye level sell better, so manufacturers want their items on these shelves. Special offers in "dump bins" attract bargain hunters. Stores also use "complementation," like placing salad dressings near salads or desserts near ice cream.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets often place basic items like bread, tea, and sugar far from the entrance. This way, customers pass by more expensive items on their way. Similarly, chain stores put popular products far from the entrance, trusting loyal customers will find them and see other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from stacking items high and selling them cheap. Instead, they display fewer items to make them seem exclusive. This strategy is about good store design as much as it is about the clothes themselves.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total bill rather than individual prices. Supermarkets use this by mixing low-profit staples with high-profit items. Not everything in a supermarket is cheap. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as "loss leaders." More often, they buy in bulk or meet sales targets to get discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, customers buy fewer items and notice individual prices more. Pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing also helps reduce theft, as staff must record the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully plan their lighting. Chain stores aim for natural light so customers see the true color of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look better.

**H. Walk This Way**

Chain stores use different carpets to guide customers. One pattern marks the main paths, and another marks sales areas. This "Yellow Brick Road" approach isn't always successful, as some shoppers stick to the main paths. Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths, leading to more inviting carpeted sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

When you enter a supermarket, you might see large photos of delicious food, which can be tempting if you're hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets use "video trolleys" with screens that show ads as you shop. Sensors trigger ads based on where you are, like showing a ready-made meal ad near the chilled food section. These trolleys target impulse buyers and reportedly boost sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, aged 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-69, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in a book called "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris contacted Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris the basics of sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while, then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went ashore to practice climbing. The climb was challenging, but Robin impressed Chris with his calmness in difficult situations. At one point, they reached a big drop, and Chris showed Robin how to climb down safely. Robin, used to climbing down ropes on his boat, managed to lower himself safely.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin developed a strong friendship. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin's leadership. Although the skipper usually makes all the decisions, Robin involved everyone in the decision-making process. Chris found the sailing part of the trip boring and challenging, as he preferred being on land. Robin, on the other hand, enjoyed working on the boat and fixing things. Chris sometimes felt useless, which was difficult for him. The yacht was crowded, with six people on a boat meant for four, unlike a mountain expedition where you can have some space.

When they reached Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the expedition. He found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety, as a fall could have been dangerous for both of them. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was tougher than Chris expected. Robin, not a natural climber, impressed Chris with his determination. On their first attempt, they climbed for 24 hours straight, and on the way down, they were so tired they almost fell asleep on steep slopes. Despite the challenges, Robin trusted Chris completely and was willing to try climbing the mountain again, even though he was worried about the boat.

The only time their friendship was tested was on the way back home. They took turns keeping watch on the yacht. Chris was supposed to take over at 4 am, but Robin let him sleep, thinking he could handle it himself. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin quickly reassured him that it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland expedition, Chris realized that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, people spat out apple seeds, and 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but most didn't suit the British climate. The Normans brought better varieties, and British monks continued to develop new apples. Many Western apples today come from these varieties.

**Medieval Apples (1200)**  
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, named for its pear-like shape, was a main dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the late 1600s, giving us the word 'costermonger' for street fruit sellers. Apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple growing. Harris brought back grafts, including the famous Pippins, and started a modern orchard in Kent.

**Apples Abroad (1750)**  
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed,' planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a medicine man by Native Americans and became a folk hero.

**Modern Apples (1850)**  
Around this time in Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree's roots. He named the apple 'Hawkey,' and it was later called 'Delicious' after a judge tasted it. It became one of the most popular apples worldwide. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith discovered another famous apple. Known as 'Granny Smith,' she found a new apple tree in 1868 and grew the first major crop of green apples, which became famous globally.

**Uniformity Concerns (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their appearance and ability to travel rather than taste. This lack of variety is reducing the gene pool. While UK gardeners have preserved many old varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are now asking for more variety. We need to protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unique destinations with interesting itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people, making them small and informal. They are led by experts, giving you a chance to learn more about the places we visit. This personal involvement helps you connect with local cultures and people, making the experience stimulating for all travelers.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport, often on the same trip. This includes chartered coaches, local buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip adapts to the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people ready to face new situations. They mainly come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are aged 25-55, with about half being couples and the rest solo adventurers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each Explore Worldwide trip is unique, so we have divided our adventures into 8 categories based on main activities and interests. Each category highlights a special part of a tour, but many factors contribute to the success of our trips, such as unique places, unusual encounters, and personal involvement.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural focus, with some tours emphasizing local cultures, ethnic groups, and historical sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Short day walks to off-the-beaten-path sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris visit the world's greatest game parks, offering thrilling encounters with animals. In Africa, you can step out of your safari vehicle to explore. Activities include tracking gorillas in Zaire, bush walking in Uganda, climbing Mount Kenya, canoeing on the Zambezi River, or riding a mokoro in the Okavango Delta. Most safaris involve camping, with some offering hotel or lodge stays. In Asia and South America, we stay in hotels, resthouses, and jungle lodges. In the Galapagos Islands, we live aboard a small motor yacht.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, like the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and minimize cultural and environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walks through countryside or village-to-village hiking, with overnight stays in private houses or village huts. Destinations include Spain, Provence, Tuscany, Crete, Corsica, Greece, Morocco, Turkey, Bulgaria, Thailand, Bhutan, Nepal, and Venezuela. Main luggage is transported separately, so you only need a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer major treks for strong walkers, sometimes at high altitudes. We may stay with locals or camp in mountain ranges like the Atlas, Himalayas, and Andes. Support vehicles or porters carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is a thrilling adventure. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert, offering a chance for a unique travel experience.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve chartering local boats. We sail through Egypt, Turkey, Greece, and Thailand, and explore the Indonesian Archipelago and the Galapagos Islands.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River journeys range from a few hours to several days, using inflatables or whitewater rafts. No experience is needed, and safety skills are quickly learned. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon offer insights into exotic jungles.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. This camp is located in Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya, and has been his base for winter training for three years. However, he had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until his fourth visit. During this trip, he participated in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in a World Championship race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. This was a great opportunity for him.

Training at high altitudes helps produce more red blood cells, improving oxygen capacity. This has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners. Richard's first race in Africa was an international cross-country race in Nairobi, the first of its kind on the continent. Although he finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, he felt he had performed well.

Richard believes that Kenyan success is not just due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to running, with an effortless style, a basic diet, and a love for competition. The key to their success might be their training methods. At the national team training camp, located at St Mark's College on Mount Kenya, athletes live simply, sharing rooms and focusing on their training.

Their daily routine includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon, covering about 40 kilometers each day. Sundays are easier, with only a 20-kilometer run. Life at the camp is uncomplicated, with simple meals and basic facilities. After training, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers.

By the end of his stay, Richard appreciated Kenyan success even more. He realized that their achievements are not just due to genetics, upbringing, or altitude. The simple lifestyle, tough training, and passion for success are likely the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Advertising is struggling, and it's not just because of the recession. The decline started in 1989, before the recession hit hard. The main issue is that advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers still think in terms of mass markets and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, target markets have become more fragmented. Major brand campaigns should focus on smaller, specific audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Consider your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items, but many of these won't be advertised brands. You might buy several of the same brand, but out of the 15,000 products available, you only purchase a few advertised ones. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For bigger items like cars, you might buy one every three years, and it might even be provided by your employer. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even when you include things like candy, medicine, and services, you likely don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Now, compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. If we focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising, the average person buys only 400 of them, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4%. So, the old saying that half of advertising is wasted might be wrong; it could be 96% that's wasted, but no one knows which part.

When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16, or 6%. The rest, 94%, seem wasted. You might think you're not influenced by ads, but most people think that too. The truth is, people don't buy most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. It's unrealistic to think everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable.

However, advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will respond, because advertisers can't know in advance who will be interested. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with many people. But all waste is unpleasant. With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who might respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail campaigns don't get a 100% response.

This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. That can't happen with media. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media; they could contact those people directly. This applies to all types of ads, from personal announcements to soft drink commercials. An advertiser who gains one million new customers (2% of the adult population) is doing well. For example, the top-selling soap powder brands would be thrilled with a million new customers. Any campaign that wins over 2% of the population is very successful, but that's still a small part of the population. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more precisely than ever before.

Text: 'Solar Survivor Charles Clover explores Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', designed by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It blends with the town's nineteenth-century buildings and was approved by planners even though it's in a conservation area. The solar-powered doorbell is silent, and the house is super-insulated with triple-glazed windows filled with krypton gas, making it very quiet inside. Once inside, you must take off your shoes, and there is a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it ventilates the house. Vale opens ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have their own air-locked door. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been committed to the environment since the 1970s. They wrote a book on green architecture called The Autonomous House. They designed a building that emits no carbon dioxide and decided to do without mains water. They created composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to protect drinking water, which is filtered before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they don't use a dishwasher to avoid strong detergents. Most features of the house are designed to be environmentally friendly. 'We wanted to show that it's possible to design a house that is less harmful to the environment without living in the dark,' says Robert. 'It wouldn't be medieval.' The only medieval aspect is the aesthetic: the hall, with the hearth and staircase, rises the full height of the building. The Vales pay no water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p, which is what other four-bedroom houses use on top of heating. Soon, the house will use even less electricity when solar panels and generating equipment are installed in the garden. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will generate extra electricity. There will even be enough to charge an electric car one day. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which the Vales rarely use. Is it warm in winter? One February night, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room temperature was 18C, which is comfortable because there are no draughts or heat loss. Perceived temperature depends on these factors. An Edwardian lady in the early 1900s was comfortable at 12.5C because of her clothing's insulation. Robert suggests people in old houses should live like people did back then, but this idea might not catch on. The house's secret is its simplicity, with little to go wrong. Most materials were bought from a builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen, making the house cheap to build, costing the same per square metre as low-cost housing for rent. Commercial building companies are resisting this idea.'

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a logical person, almost like a scientist. However, in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies taken in a garden, he believed they were real evidence that fairies existed. He published these photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural beings. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simple trick challenges the idea that a camera always tells the truth. In fact, it can lie, and it always could. Today, we are familiar with using computer software to change our digital images, and it's a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the start, when cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

Text: 'Blacksmiths Throughout history, iron has fascinated people, and those who work with it, blacksmiths, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who could make weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created the elaborate ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were always made by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s in Britain, these skills were almost lost because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs. In the past 10 years, there has been a revival due to more interest in decorative architecture and a more open-minded approach to interior design. Still, much of the work seems old-fashioned: makers of gates and balconies often describe their products as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. You can't enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with hanging decorations. Fortunately, there are other options, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmiths' craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says: 'We might be at the start of a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently.' Power tools have freed blacksmiths from hard work over a hot anvil, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. 'In short,' says Dawson, 'these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.' About 250 pieces have been made for the show, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, 'but a percentage of every sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork,' says Dawson. His own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. 'My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space,' he says. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging. Susan May, a jeweler by training, says, 'It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes really hard and unmovable again.' Ann Catrin Evans' steel door-knockers and handles seem inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. 'I love that steel is cold and hard,' she says. 'And it feels like it will last forever.' No other common metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are high, as long as we don't have to see any more rusty candlesticks, that is.'

Title: THE DAY I QUIT SMOKING

When I quit smoking, I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was really angry. She said, "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to a non-smoker in just four hours, and I found it strange myself.

The session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn't planned to quit and didn't really want to. I was annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking campaigns, and I still am. I had low blood pressure, a healthy family, and I didn't feel sick. I even thought I recovered from colds faster than my health-conscious friends.

On a regular Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking in Birmingham to write an article about others trying to quit. I told them, "I won't be trying to stop myself; it wouldn't be fair." I was there to write, not to quit, so I didn't expect their method to work on me. I actually enjoyed smoking; it gave me pleasure. The counselor seemed to understand this.

We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when we were told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. The messages about quitting made sense to me. Just as smoking had been a challenge against opposition, quitting started to feel appealing. The idea of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling, just for me. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, which felt like hunger, faded after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I believed I couldn't meet deadlines without nicotine, but I was wrong. Surprisingly, spending weekend mornings at home was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was an activity itself.

Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker is different, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were all times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, yet she is not well-known in her own country. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's first biography, believes she should be a household name. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life mirrored significant changes in the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When Ferry started her research, she looked into scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin's suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, a close friend and fellow scientist who also opposed nuclear weapons. However, Ferry found no biographies of Pauling in her local bookshop, which surprised her. Pauling was a major chemist of the 20th century and won Nobel Prizes in both chemistry and peace, yet he was not well-known in Britain.

Some scientists, like the late Peter Medawar, have said that scientists' lives are often dull to read about. This view might explain why publishers and booksellers are not eager to promote scientific biographies. There is a belief in the literary world that there is a big gap between understanding the arts and sciences. As a result, only the most famous scientists are featured in bookshops.

However, scientists do not lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists avoid media attention to maintain their credibility. For example, a leading geneticist once said he did not want to be quoted or photographed to avoid being seen as self-promoting. This attitude can give a false impression of science and discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, this is changing. Scientists are now appearing in public in different ways. For instance, Professor Richard Dawkins presents TV quiz prizes, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on TV. These activities help people see scientists as relatable individuals.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be scholarly and dull, often ignoring the scientist's personal life. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which was both funny and touching. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie are shown with their flaws.

Dorothy Hodgkin was passionate about her scientific work. She solved the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin, winning the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964. She also had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

Hodgkin's life is interesting not just for her science but also for how she managed her personal and professional life. Communicating the passion for scientific inquiry is challenging for biographers because many readers lack the scientific background to understand complex ideas. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. It's unfortunate that many educated people are unaware of the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a 'sixth sense'. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers, whose wells have dried up, ask for her help. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business. They use modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers, but to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

This skill, known as dowsing, involves finding water, minerals, or lost objects underground. There are many ideas about how dowsing works. Some people think it involves physical forces like magnetism, while others believe it is more spiritual. A popular theory is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers, like Margaret, might be very good at sensing these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.

In recent years, droughts have kept the Wilkins busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of Margaret's clients are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other clients include people with remote holiday homes and golf-course developers who need water for their facilities.

Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She avoids drilling where farm waste could contaminate the water. The water she finds flows through cracks in solid rock, which helps keep it clean. However, in Cornwall, where they work, there is a lot of iron, so they have to be careful. They also need electricity to power the pump, so the well should be near existing power lines.

To find water on large properties like golf courses, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when it is over an area with water. After identifying possible spots, she walks the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation and uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. She holds the stick's forks and pulls them slightly apart. When water is directly below, the stick's straight part rises. It's crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates, as even a small mistake can miss the water. Her husband also checks the area, and they only drill if they agree on the spot.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition in England. Many people are interested in this mysterious ability. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This might explain why she is so good at finding water. Without this 'sixth sense', it would be hard for her family to make a living from their well-drilling business year after year.

**We changed lives for a day!**

Have you ever thought about switching lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be exciting to try something different? We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, a 30-year-old waitress at a busy London restaurant. Amanda had never been in such a lively place before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people, which was very different from her hometown. She had to learn quickly how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. It seemed easy for the other waitresses, but Amanda struggled and ended up dropping the drinks. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed it off, saying everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line of customers had formed outside, and Amanda felt nervous. Luckily, the orders were automated, so she didn't have to remember them. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she found the loud music hard to handle. She had to keep asking customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and wanted to soak her feet. She was surprised to hear it had been a 'quiet' day. Amanda realized that waitressing is tiring and requires a bubbly personality and the ability to stay calm with many customers. She didn't like the pay and didn't receive any tips. She was happy to return to her children, finding it easier than waitressing.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a 'mum' for the day. She thought she could handle Amanda's cheeky daughters, but it was more challenging than she expected. After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls, drop Sophie at school, and Katie at nursery. She thought she would have some free time, but Amanda left a note with chores like making beds, cleaning, and doing laundry. After picking up Katie and shopping, she brought Sophie home, and the girls started jumping on the sofa and screaming. Cindy tried to stay calm, hoping they would tire out, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. She didn't realize how tiring it was to care for two small children and felt the heavy responsibility. Despite this, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, a 42-year-old dairy farmer, swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher. On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She was unsure about what to wear to school. At assembly, she faced about 400 pupils and hoped to blend in. She helped with a maths class where children worked in groups, which was different from her school days. She also assisted with a nature project involving snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but found teachers only have a short break. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson and a French lesson, where the children practiced on her, revealing her rusty French. Finally, they had Physical Education, and Rosemary was exhausted, but the children were full of energy. She found speaking in front of the class challenging. Despite teachers having more holidays, she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, surprised that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, sold in shops and restaurants. Hilary spent the morning bottling milk and packaging ice cream. It was hard to resist tasting the treats. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe, which could die if left for more than 12 hours. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children. The hardest part was not being able to take time off, as the cows need milking daily. Rosemary only gets about three days of holiday a year. Farming seems romantic, but it's tough, with irregular income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without a musical background. Hakan Hardenberger, the only child of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a standout trumpet player by the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new compositions. When you meet him, he appears youthful and energetic, much like the sound of his trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature highlighted his work and growth, filmed in both the UK and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo, and his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music despite not being musical himself, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother contacted the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, to teach her son. Nilsson, a rising musician, immediately recognized Hardenberger's talent. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher from the start, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and eager to connect with other players worldwide.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument with imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly the same. He believes in understanding these imperfections and working with them. From a young age, he had the ability to find the right balance and develop his unique sound. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances, and collected all his records.

His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and risky, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special ability to connect with audiences. Thibaud encouraged him to enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger only prepared for the first round but advanced to the second, where he knew most of the pieces. In the final, he faced a challenging concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and noticed that people listened to him, even if he thought he "played like a pig."

Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that's not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. He feels the power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It's a unique tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is known for its humor and the author's special way of seeing things, combined with deep psychological insight. It's a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she wouldn't meet someone like Sheila, who is from a working-class background and takes care of her elderly father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, neither boy talks about the incident. Leo, who was a good student and never fought before, won't say why he did it. Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author is great at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives and captures the feeling that no matter how hard a mother tries, it never seems enough.

**C.** This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. It connects this story with important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the dreams of the young main character, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to value the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After a recent successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is still a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness. Rosie helps her in her enjoyable manipulation of suitors and friends. By the end, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author is good at showing the hidden sadness in ordinary life and focuses more on the subtle aspects of human activity than the obvious ones.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses impressive descriptive language to show each person's journey of self-discovery as they prepare to return home, their spirits renewed by the experience of life at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both challenging and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers: Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and their daily routines.**

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY:**  
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work by 8 am. She begins operating at 8:30 am on Mondays, Wednesdays, and some Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. Sometimes, she works for ten hours without a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. While she doesn't feel stressed during surgery, she sometimes worries about the next day's tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but successful operations are very rewarding. From 10 am to 1 pm, she runs an out-patient clinic, explaining operations to patients. She enjoys this part of her job, although time constraints can make it hard to comfort upset patients. Anne leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. She is on call some nights and weekends, always carrying her pager. On holidays, she worries about her patients for the first few days and dreams about operating at night. She finds it difficult to relax.

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY:**  
Marita gets up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss their projects and any issues. Her team includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of her work is design; the rest is production. She receives a brief from the client and spends three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting her ideas to the client and getting approval, she works on estimates and budgets, and hires photographers and illustrators. She coordinates with printers to ensure everything is on schedule. Managing people and multiple projects can be stressful, with deadlines always approaching. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, often at a pub, or she eats sandwiches while working. It's satisfying when clients like her designs, but disappointing when projects are rejected. She gets home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later, and finds it hard to unwind.

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY:**  
Linda usually wakes up at 7 am, but on days she meets early flights, she gets up between 4:30 am and 5 am. Around 10:30 or 11 am, she might go for a bike ride or swim. Since driving is a sedentary job, she watches her diet and exercises regularly. She has a big breakfast and snacks during the day. Clients often ask for recommendations on restaurants and shops, so she needs to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing her to plan routes. Not all passengers are polite, but most are well-behaved, and she has good relationships with regular clients. She sometimes overhears conversations in the car but stays focused on driving. The press has tried to get her to talk about clients, but she refuses. Linda works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and tries to be in bed by 11 pm.

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY:**  
Tracy gets up at 7 am, leaves home at 7:30 am, and starts her first job. She and her assistant mainly maintain gardens they have designed. They do some commercial work, but mostly private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each. Around 11 am, they take a break for a big breakfast at a cafe. In summer, she may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. Her business office is at home, where she checks messages and returns calls. If someone wants their garden landscaped, she arranges evening consultations. They use old materials and unusual plants to create gardens that look aged. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't appealing, but it's satisfying to see a garden completed and blooming. Tracy finds it hard to relax in the evenings because she can hear the business phone. She sleeps well because the physical work is tiring. The job is tough but allows for creativity.

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY:**  
Zena arrives at the construction site by 8:30 am. As an assistant resident engineer, she oversees the building of bridges and a retaining wall. She ensures contractors follow the schedule, safety rules, and minimize environmental impact. She coordinates site professionals and solves problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so she first checks with the clerk of works about any updates. Her day involves reacting to this information, handling paperwork, and answering design questions. Lunch is usually a quick half-hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm. When contractors are on break, it's easier for her to inspect the site. Checking their work can cause tension, so she maintains open communication. She meets the duty resident engineer daily but acts immediately if urgent issues arise. Zena leaves the site around 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I handle customer programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards program in major European markets. I need to stay in touch with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then reply to emails. I manage all advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes 10 to 20 demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists, involving the press, marketing, and the managing director. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive because it's important to the artists. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7:00 pm at the earliest and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly work-related, and I often get home at 1:00 am, where I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, buying from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with a full-time restorer and coordinate with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette during coffee breaks to stay updated on the business and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work set shifts, leaving home at 6:00 am for early shifts. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a half-hour break before switching stations. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, and we control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing time to read up on new air traffic requirements between 12 and 4:00 am. It's crucial to be alert, so I don't hesitate to take sick leave if needed. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I aim to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating when they expect me to gather many books based on reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss new titles for the upcoming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When featuring a new title, I ensure timely delivery. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Twice a week, I work a late shift, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
