'Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite as well.'

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps end the night at Dick's T-Bar,' she says. However, Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work starts earlier on Sunday, as breakfast for departing guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet thoroughly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. 'I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.'

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a ride back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. Soon, it's time for dinner duty again, and maybe a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour asking to see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago. Marie's father had shown them how he made gloves, especially Marie's favorite spot, the laying-off table. At this table, the workers shaped and pressed each glove by carefully pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet.' 'Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you want. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I think. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was interesting once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; he's the one you should talk to. Start him on gloves, and he'll talk for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have.' 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. An innocent with spirit, eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. The good-natured intelligence that filled the house when Marie came home from school, full of what she'd learned in class. How she remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to show you the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

**It's a Tough Job?**

Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**

Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often has to travel suddenly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss, but she has one small issue—she hates flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down," she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde because it felt cramped with small windows. When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. Her tasks include organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and handling paperwork. She didn't apply for the job; she met a pop group's manager by chance, which led to a job offer. She also took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a PA.

**B. David Brown**

David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. He preferred being a caddy because he loves golf. However, the job has downsides. Caddies earn a small fee plus a percentage of the golfer's winnings. Average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of this goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at age 31. "You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge of the weather, and trying to understand the course," he says. His accounting skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes daily play statistics from caddies' cards, which are used by TV commentators, golf magazines, and golfers.

**C. Martin Fern**

Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is trying food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an advertising agency, and the column was a good extra income. At 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**

"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words and wrote mostly poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about the problem of foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story called 'The Fox Busters,' which was my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out my morning notes on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, which is the part of being a writer I enjoy most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. One afternoon, with nothing else to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof, landing on the sawdust and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. They looked down, nervous and pale, but one by one, they jumped and felt relieved. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Eventually, one friend said, "Let's go back up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they climbed back up and jumped off again, determined, until only Michael was left on the roof. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge, licking his lips nervously, wondering why it seemed so much higher this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and taking deep breaths, but he couldn't jump. The others started laughing, tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they began to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour as the sun set, a big orange ball in the sky. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, and fell heavily onto the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little gray in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled sternness, but Michael, feeling gloomy and miserable, barely heard her. He kept seeing his friends' grinning faces and hearing their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your current job but unsure how to make a change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change careers are turning to career advisers for guidance. The process usually involves writing a brief history of yourself and taking several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help identify your strengths and suggest possible career paths, along with any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that provides career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions quickly. It was important to remember that the test wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on this chat and the test results, the adviser created a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, although I was surprised to learn I didn't do well in scientific, technical, and practical tests. It's probably a good thing I didn't become a nurse! However, it was reassuring to hear that I made the right choice in pursuing journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a big shift. For example, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company after five years. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. "Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career," says Donna. Some results were unexpected. "I didn't realize I had a talent for design, but I had to consider the cost of retraining against my financial responsibilities," she explains. Other options included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, Donna decided to use her existing skills and moved into a more suitable role as a Public Relations officer. She believes Career Analysts helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, who are also satisfied.

Some people feel they wouldn't have made career changes without help. Juliet Greene, 26, visited Career Counselling Services and made significant life decisions. After working at a major bank for six years, she found her job boring and wanted a new challenge. With no clear idea of what to do, she approached Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed she had an interest in sciences. After four sessions with an adviser, she decided to pursue geology and plans to start a degree course soon. Juliet feels the advice was worth the cost and is now much happier and more positive.

However, career advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, felt stuck in her career and hoped a career adviser would offer new ideas. Although she received many suggestions, she rejected them because they required a significant pay cut or extensive retraining. Amanda felt she didn't learn anything new about herself and thought a friend could have given similar advice with the same information.

Title: 'A New Experience at the Dentist's'

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch for patients. Jerome explains that half of the people only visit the dentist when they are in pain, not for regular check-ups, because they are scared. To change this, he has created a welcoming environment. He doesn't wear a white coat because it reminds people of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even enjoyable.

This idea is surprising for many who think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says that if people are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their past bad experiences. One of his new techniques is using virtual-reality headsets. His practice was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth, which most patients find interesting.

The dental office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome believes that smell is important because the typical dental smell can make people anxious. The pleasant smell helps people feel calm.

Although Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but the quality of treatment is the top priority. For example, he uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It might feel strange at first, but it doesn't hurt if you're relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He discovered that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He believes this approach will gradually make British dentistry less formal.

As a patient arrives, Jerome offers him a cup of tea and asks what video he would like to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The dental office feels more like a beauty salon than a typical dentist's office.

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, which is when 8% of all chocolate is bought. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. Although chocolate began to be made in large amounts in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it started in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate. At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, first called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular thanks to advertising that linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside. Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week, so manufacturers are finding new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the 'extended line,' where a chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, soft drink, or dessert to appeal to those tired of regular snacks. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices from the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, perhaps think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83 years old, has become an expert in his art. He still wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the last ten years. As he shows me around his apartment, he says, "Tell me if I am boring you." However, Peter is not boring at all; he is enthusiastic and charming, and his creations are beautiful.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says, "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I love them. I never planned to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends visited and said, 'You should have an exhibition. People need to see these. We'll talk to a gallery owner.'" This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, and the pieces are quite expensive, with some costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase.

Peter says he doesn't set the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his. The gallery owner told him, "One day you'll stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more." Peter wishes he had started this work earlier in life, as he feels he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has ideas, he admits he is more physically limited now than when he began.

His work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which has led to intricate boxes covered in tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers. Peter has developed his own techniques, using materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," but the detail, color, and symmetry in his work show careful planning.

Peter's search for beautiful, especially small, shells has taken him beyond his local Norfolk shore to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people crushing them with their feet faster than I can collect them; and the sea breaks up the rest. I would never collect shells with living creatures or dive for them, but once they are empty, why shouldn't I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty he creates from these shells.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm sorry, Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I was trying to ignore all the negative things I'd heard about models, like being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. And now she was late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she came with her mother. Kira wasn't wearing expensive designer clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mom, very proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister was the one who thought she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should try it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When she got the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now finds it challenging to balance her two lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I think too highly of myself." This must be tough for Kira, as she's not self-important at all. But she says, "They think that because I've become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even finish their school exams. As I finish the interview with the girl who has it all, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have the beauty that seems sure to take her to the top of the modeling world. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat to find valuable metals. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find high levels of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing away plants and finding bits of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have some people we can contact."

As news spread about their dig, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but if they find gold, I hope millions won't come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she goes on deep-sea dives in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last up to 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested this yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first dive, where she was tested on emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. She has now completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. This area has many underwater volcanoes with chimneys that release black smoke. The Russian team was installing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a speed of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls a frightening experience during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. Fortunately, nothing happened, and the relief was immense.

For Rachel, diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is often the first person to see these parts of the ocean. After studying black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an incredible experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign schedules, money, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere I wanted in Europe. Once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds never feel the same. The train's rhythm rocks you into a deep sleep. Carrying everything you own in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to throwing away things like socks that are too smelly or books when you're done with them. This way of thinking fits perfectly with the spirit of Inter-Rail, where common sense and reasoning can be ignored, just like the socks and books. All you need for this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the possibilities of this train ticket at first. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting because there was always one more country just over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We weren't completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and when planning our own schedule, we only included the most easily accessible sights. This was a chance to escape the guided tour and do something different. I was proud that, in many places, all I bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was just a name before. It's as if the city you arrive in never really existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have a clear picture of the continent in your mind. Everyone knows what's there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are so boring. While the train trip won't let you discover anything new in a global sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to realize this, though in our case, it didn't happen right away.

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out your baggage is missing is very disappointing. At best, you might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you could be in a completely different climate, far from home, with clothes that are not suitable. Airlines don't often say how many bags they lose, but frequent travelers know that losing luggage happens sometimes. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will always be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, which can cause the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause problems. These issues are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs,' because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport managed over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports, like Miami in the United States, where luggage often goes missing when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline for the whole trip. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James, a wildlife photographer, is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. The bird moves quickly and brightly through its environment, leaving a lasting impression despite its small size. Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young, but he can't quite explain why he is so drawn to them. The kingfisher is part of legends, like the Greek myth where it is a moon goddess turned into a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers have no blue pigment; their feathers reflect light in a way that makes them look blue or green depending on the light angle. This makes them fascinating to wildlife photographers. Kingfishers are shy but can be watched from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. It took him four years to get a good picture. The European kingfisher became a big part of his life, but school got in the way, so he skipped classes and didn't do well academically. However, his passion was noticed, and at 16, he became an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant editor and then became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film with just beautiful images and no words. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his deep feelings for the bird, but he knows there's more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can express.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, got her big break when she asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I've always been comfortable in front of an orchestra," she says. Manson, originally from the U.S., works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, supported by the British Arts Council. Since her first opportunity, she has worked with Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is convincing people to give you the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. Looking back, he feels the timing was perfect: "If it had happened earlier, I might have disappeared without a trace." The competition opened many doors for him, including a role as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being labeled as just a "competition winner." "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I'll be concerned," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If that doesn't happen, your career can fall apart."

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always been taught by much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are lots of arguments, and you have to consider the singers' personalities."

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
"Conducting came as a surprise to me, but it's very interesting," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It's not a completely unexpected career change, though. He started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something new for him. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and had a clear idea of how I wanted it to sound. I tried my best to achieve that. People respect my musical ability. I'm using all my past experiences, both in music style and performance. Now, I'll do whatever people ask to find out what I enjoy."

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor, Wayne Marshall, and mentioned him to his agent. Marshall, now 32, soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was challenging. He even had to deal with some musicians reading newspapers during the show. "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and got the best result I could. Many orchestral musicians don't seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I'm not afraid to say what I want. If people see you're worried, it gets worse. I've never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old had a lot of fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is also a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly and helpful. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, especially the trapeze act, which was thrilling. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is great for younger children. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very noticeable, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for a few of them but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't have dared to tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly income of over £200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. Christine wanted a job she could do from home. She had experience with computers, so her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with finances, always informing the bank if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, and local customers usually pick up their orders.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after marrying and moving to the countryside, she started her own business. She creates 50 different greeting cards, selling them to museums. Maggy works in a large room at home. A downside of working from home is the constant household tasks, like mowing the lawn. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send her work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her work.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business that has had ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She once managed six full-time workers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was hard because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. Delia adjusts her prices when needed and looks for new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the country. Tessa enjoys flexible working hours. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop, earning £250,000 a year and employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, focusing on healthy fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, employing a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg now manages the business side and no longer bakes. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as they started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians and composers, while their father, John, makes musical instruments. 

When Paul was ten years old, his parents, John and Hetty, wanted to buy him a cello because he was getting really good at playing. However, they found that cellos were very expensive. John decided to try making one himself. He found a school nearby that taught instrument making and attended evening classes for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It turned out well, and he later made another one that Paul used for many years.

John eventually left his teaching job to become a full-time instrument maker. He now makes about twelve violins a year. One of his violins was even bought by the famous American violinist Jaime Laredo, which was a big achievement for him.

Both Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano and then became interested in the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin, but he preferred the cello after meeting a cellist he admired. Huw was also encouraged to play music but chose the piano and composing instead of the violin.

Paul has achieved a lot with the cello his father made. He won a major music competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Recently, he started playing a very old and valuable cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan to him. He says his father's cello is great, but the Rugeri projects sound better in large concert halls.

Paul will soon be on television playing the Rugeri cello in a famous piece, Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won't be able to watch it because he will be performing at a festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will be performed in London for the first time. Their parents, John and Hetty, will have to work hard to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders.

Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden job on the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth got it because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. He still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' issues and communicate with them effectively. His farming background also makes him fit for the physical tasks of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls.

Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault, as they were following government advice. Initially, farmers and conservationists disagreed, but now they are starting to understand each other. Gareth believes they are close to working together.

Conservation is a big part of Gareth's job, along with allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, maintaining the land, and meeting with tenant farmers. He ensures that tasks are completed efficiently and economically. Gareth enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even though he is always on duty. He enjoys talking to the public, although he finds some people's attitudes frustrating. They sometimes act as if they own the land. Despite this, Gareth believes common sense is key to the job. If you have common sense and like working outdoors, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for the World Championships next month. Her days are busy: she teaches at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people give her strange looks while she trains. She said, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's it."

Kendra's life is all about being in top shape for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest yet, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have support from the home crowd, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure because the home crowd has high expectations. They want us to start the tournament well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they are exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." England is currently ranked fourth in the world. Kendra notes that the World Championships are challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win overall, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, so you must be ready."

In her 15 years of playing at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But after the final whistle, we become different people. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and must lead by example. My role is to support and encourage the team."

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should you support a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can handle children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. These schools create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one-third to half of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school full-time, which means they spend their formative years with others who have similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question whether it's wise to admit children as young as seven into such a focused and disciplined setting. They emphasize that their main goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer help and advice when needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering a specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with music training at a junior department of a music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with great teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially along the two long flower borders next to the path that goes from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, 'It was really his garden.' They got along well, and although Danny sometimes doubted her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan likes to paint detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, 'I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day, becoming more interesting.

Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers, thinking they looked fake. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden includes plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas, which thrive as if they were always there. Susan has a relaxed approach to gardening, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of flowers to paint, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She hired another gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experience as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year working there, where she cooks and cleans for visitors staying in chalets, which are typical wooden houses in the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She sees being a chalet girl not as a career but as a fun way to spend a couple of years before settling down. "It's a great way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah doesn't live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing a full breakfast for the guests, including porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys skiing as much as possible. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she avoids napping. "It's a mistake if you do," she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., with coffee by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than a messy kitchen in the morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make the week fantastic, but some weeks aren't as great."

Sarah meets her friends at her chalet and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, then maybe go to G Jay's, and end at Dick's T-Bar," she says. However, she doesn't stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "and you don't want to be tired while cooking breakfast." On Sundays, she starts work earlier, with breakfast ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans thoroughly, stripping beds and preparing everything for the new guests. If she hasn't shopped on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions, which she attributes to the mountain air.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment and gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Then it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't usually stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, because of my shifts, I don't see daylight. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was fine. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it was very satisfying."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and it made me feel different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat super healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this, but it inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers amazing views of the sea. No matter the weather or time of year, it's always beautiful. From the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable - we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages - some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming took place on an old, unused part of the line, maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it was like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

If you want to get your story published, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some advice for you. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing you need to do is research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the publishing world. No matter what you write, you need to know the market you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading as much relevant material as you can. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are looking for at any time. Keep updating your knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. 

If you're unsure what to write, for example, short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on meeting their readers' needs. Writers often ask me, "My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I don't discourage anyone, but if your work isn't publishable, I give honest feedback with a positive outlook. Many new writers send their work too soon, often before they're ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each one will improve, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station, which usually felt airy and clean, seemed crowded. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl standing near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn't mind talking to her. The man asked, 'Are you going to Philadelphia by any chance?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, and moved to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' I heard him ask an old lady, 'are you going to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't say anything, just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I stood up straight and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't. I probably seemed unreliable to him. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the bench at the other end of the waiting area. He looked really stressed now. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty, maybe thirty-five - older than me. She looked like a schoolteacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favor?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my left wrist. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like big pets on leashes. Then I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She barely said "hello" to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called home from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where he was going with this. 'So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would find someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was such an emergency? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a weak excuse, in my opinion. Also, it seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at the two of them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have made more sense, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Be careful, lady, I thought to myself.'

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. 

I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity to own a restaurant, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory and me feeling upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very beneficial for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a very energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into our corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had plenty of money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very academic, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had a natural talent. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for my school course,' I sent him to a friend who owns a restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music career takes off. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can achieve. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to succeed in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping other people. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm extremely proud of him. I've always tried to tell him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything for free. He's seen the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You know, you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But for Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had no one to tell her about a vacant bedsit at the end of the month. So, she stayed in a hostel and searched for a place. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; it was just assumed by everyone at her school that she would leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That's all she had heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently, as it was run by nuns and safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who seemed to have been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing. "Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo realized Pauline was a punk, which surprised her. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one before. "I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs. One had "Nessa," one had "Pauline," and the other had "Other" written on it. "We'll put your name on it if you stay," Nessa said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them at seaside marinas, in movies, and on TV. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds explains how dolphin numbers are decreasing.

Dolphins are special to us because they are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" with its star dolphin, Darwin, have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. For example, the number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000.

You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and without plans to protect them, we might face a major wildlife disaster. There are 40 different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups, quickly passing ships, so we know little about them. The larger bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were once found along the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales, and the few that remain show signs of stress.

Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to pinpoint why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also affects dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished in one area, they might not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall, with marks and cuts showing they were caught in these nets.

Pollution is another problem. Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies.
