For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and these poisons accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high levels of pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case where a young dolphin died from its mother's poisoned milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air, which might disturb dolphins in ways we don't yet understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but it's really beneficial for you. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to, for most people.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It increases muscle power and helps you stand or sit with good posture. Good posture is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Exercise also prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. It quickly improves areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It also makes your heart, lungs, and blood circulation better.

You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored by them. But here's something interesting: exercise can help reduce depression and tiredness, and it helps you sleep better. It also helps control stress and can relieve some medical conditions. These reasons should convince you that exercise is good for you. If not, just using common sense should tell you that exercise is beneficial.

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, lifting free weights, or using weight machines. Remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injuries, so start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is important for improving your body shape. It affects how you look and feel. A stiff or slouching body doesn't look good, lacks energy, and can have minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head up. This will help lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer. When standing with a balanced chest, you should be able to see your ankles.

Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and makes movement easier. It helps maintain good posture and prevents muscle injuries. Stretching four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. So, stretching should be an important part of your exercise routine. Do it slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? It's their quest for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, finding producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman can be as challenging as spotting the wildlife they film. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has faced six months of almost nonstop rain, causing unexpected problems. Newman mentioned they had to buy an expensive tool to help when their vehicles get stuck in the mud, allowing Amanda to pull him out safely.

Their teamwork has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their popular film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's shy leopards was airing, they were back in the wild, this time filming the equally shy jackal. This is common for TV partnerships. Traveling film-makers have been exploring the world to capture exotic wildlife since TV began.

I talked to Newman about their partnership during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue, but we get over it quickly,' he says about Amanda. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view animals similarly. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now, we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each day, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a bit of a worry,' says Newman.

Living in remote areas can be tough, but it allows them to get close to the animals. Newman recalls filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift,' and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. They now spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I have always worked well together because we share the same ideas and vision,' says Newman. 'We aim to create films rich in atmosphere that capture the true spirit of the place and animals, touching people's hearts. I believe it's better to evoke an emotional response than just appeal to people's intellect.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is preparing for the World Championships next month. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location and asked if people stare. She said, "I'm too focused on my movements and feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's it."

Kendra's life is all about being in top shape for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure and expectations from the home crowd. People expect us to start strong."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." England is currently ranked fourth in the world. Kendra notes that the World Championships are challenging. "You have to play every day without rest. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win, but in the Championships, you only have one chance."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But after the game, we're all friendlier." Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. As captain, she believes in having a strong mental attitude and leading by example. Her role is to support and encourage her team.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye, with her loyal supporters cheering her on.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers down into the ocean in a small steel vehicle to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very tight. Rachel can touch the two pilots because there is so little room. They can't stand up or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days west of the Canary Islands. There, they studied a large area of underwater volcanoes, where black smoke comes out of chimneys on the ocean floor. The Russian team was setting up equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When she's not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water flows at one meter per second and is 350 degrees hot.

Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she sees the chimneys through the porthole, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has seen before. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body language, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to present yourself in the best way." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't turn him down. So, he offered me a lower salary than I hoped for. I'm sure I could have gotten more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it can help make an interview successful. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive impression and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but I was suddenly made redundant. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a top local hotel. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm happy not to be in an office anymore, but surprisingly, I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, and I was probably the first to say, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children were independent. We moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us."

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner with even more hours, so I left. People thought I'd get bored, but I haven't. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the product."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, making deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find it rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future."

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many different ones, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are very serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it's worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home, hang out with friends, and do normal things. You can't focus on the sport all the time; it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I've only been recognized in public a few times, which is good because I don't want to be a celebrity. I get many letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's amazing to walk on the court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. I still enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping, but it has downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports and be professional. It doesn't bother me much now. I'm focused on my game and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

Title: Shopping with Children

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says it's very stressful because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she buys them. But she also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets upset even before leaving the house. She tries not to take them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a shopping trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when ads make products look so appealing.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy products, so even if they can't directly tell children to ask their parents, the ads still have that effect.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a big source of stress for parents. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and advertisements, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his children because they're unhealthy, but he buys treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent because his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without their children's demands might attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to transform four large 18th-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests.

At the Merrion, General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, like guests' preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is very positive about its efficiency and features. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can record many preferences.

Guests often complain about room temperature in hotels. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

For guests, especially business travelers, the technology in their rooms is very appealing. MacCann estimates that up to 65% of the hotel's business will come from business travelers. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future updates. Extra cables have been installed to handle new technology. The televisions are rented, not bought, so they can be replaced with newer models anytime. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann says they have tried to make guests feel comfortable, not overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud's Dublin restaurant, which already had two Michelin stars, is now part of the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He has a new, modern kitchen and better parking facilities. For the hotel, they offer a popular and successful dining option without financial risks.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share how they stay energized.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get energy from excitement and challenges. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. Activities with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, are energizing for me. Dance is expressive and uplifting. I think boredom can make you feel tired and like life has no purpose. Being productive, even in small ways, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a burden. Enjoying what you do keeps you from feeling down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel great. When I only get six hours, I feel a bit sluggish. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week and try to exercise at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I get tired in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's my natural enthusiasm and positive attitude. I dislike negativity. I believe we should enjoy life and seize the moment. Enjoyment is key. Achieving goals is important. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people is energizing. I enjoy a busy life and being sociable. I like taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun. It's a good mental release when I travel."

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. I enjoy working with kids because they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural reaction from interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise routine. I get active by playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love turning a wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area by breaking it up and adding soil. It was better than any workout. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy. I find it hard to write without an audience. I also enjoy exploring private lands like a child, even if I get caught."

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"I believe in having interest and respect for what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you dislike drains your energy. I used to be on committees and didn't like the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus it on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. People used these bone skates until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, modern skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually make longer movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should learn. Even professional skaters fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you'll notice how relaxed and smooth they are. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises are important, especially for the legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to focus on each day. When I'm extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people from all over the world and gained confidence."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love show-jumping events; they are exciting and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started when she was 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, she should reach her potential."

It's true - we're all getting taller

When Chris Greener was fourteen, he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller on average. More and more very tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're becoming a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our ancient size, like our caveman ancestors. We're finally overcoming the effects of poor diets from the past, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We're becoming like the Cro-Magnons again, who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. Some tribes still live this way. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide over half of the world's calories. This limited diet has harmed our health and growth. Over time, we've eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us undernourished. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was actually a health problem, according to some experts. Despite this, farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. Only recently have wealthier countries started to improve nutrition. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like those of our ancestors. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it brings challenges. While people are getting taller, beds have stayed the same length since 1860, and legroom in planes and trains seems to be shrinking. Clothing companies also have to adjust their sizes. The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University suggests it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century.

However, scientists note that while individuals are getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly taller and rounder to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller, even with good nutrition. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink more. So, global warming could counteract our growth.

**Studio Audiences: What It's Like to Be Part of One**

Have you ever wondered what it's like to be in the audience when a TV show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this experience. Studio audiences are a regular part of TV production, but they can seem mysterious to many of us. When we see them getting excited on game shows, we might wonder: who are these people?

Some people think studio audiences are not very prestigious. I've heard that even TV professionals don't always respect them, treating them poorly, like one cameraman who compared them to cattle. I used to think studio audiences were just people looking for a brief moment of fame. However, there's no single type of person in a studio audience. They come from all walks of life, with different jobs and incomes. TV shows try to attract various types of people depending on the program.

For those of us who enjoy watching TV at home, it can be hard to understand why someone would go to a studio. Why would anyone go through the trouble of getting tickets, traveling, and sitting for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch something they could see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on TV, even for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela, who said she came for the chance to appear on TV. Another reason might be curiosity about how TV shows are made. But the most common reason I heard was simply that a friend gave them a ticket.

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You imagine sitting tightly packed with strangers, following signs that tell you when to clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said they hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.

Is there a difference between watching a show in a studio and at home? For Claire, being in a studio is more exciting, and Charlotte enjoyed feeling part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. Watching him live is different from seeing him on TV at home." Personally, I missed seeing the live actors because my view was blocked. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching them on a studio screen.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the main point. For most people in the audience, it was just a fun and free night out.

**Bruce**  
I don't like wild landscapes without any human touch. I find the human element important. When I travel, I prefer charming villages with old temples over empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham, which is in a beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I loved exploring the bare hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt familiar but also different, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by hobbyists. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery isn't spectacular. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there's one part of the journey I always look forward to—when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers can see people going about their day, like making tea or doing the dishes. I see myself through their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into their homes. It's the ordinary landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and full of rocks, so there aren't many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to admire the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through beautiful, damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns some property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There aren't many residents or visitors. It's an unknown, empty, and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found the area by chance when I was a student, and since then, I've visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in a city environment.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted pure peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the house of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day of Animal Chaos

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she found a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank ready for temporary animal guests, so we could admire them and learn more about them from our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help from their bedroom. I rushed in to find our cat, Domino, with a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino was running around the room, trying to find a place to enjoy his catch, while the kids were waving their arms to stop him. I tried to help but tripped and fell.

As I lay on the floor, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank. It was slithering across the floor while the cat, mouse, and kids were all in a chaotic mess. The dog was barking loudly, and the pot in the kitchen was boiling over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the room. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I turned my attention to the snake. It was difficult to handle, but I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it down. Eventually, the snake relaxed, and I carefully picked it up. I took it to the end of the garden, hoping it would choose to live there. When I released its head, expecting it to attack, it instead wrapped around my shoulders like a shawl.

We stood there, my four children, the snake, and I, in the evening light. My eldest, DJ, explained that the snake liked me because I was warm, unlike the garden shed. We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed up our feelings: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a letter! In today's fast-paced world with phones, fax machines, and computers, the traditional art of writing letters is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is a unique experience that no other form of communication can match. There's the excitement when it arrives, the joy of seeing who it's from, and finally, the pleasure of reading it. Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Sometimes my father would write, and it was always a delight to receive his long, funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday events involving my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it's the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I often dated people who had to work or study far away, and we could only stay in touch through letters. Instead of hurting the relationships, writing letters seemed to make them better. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by speaking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! It's even more exciting when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from a holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we regularly write to each other. I can improve my French (she doesn't speak English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success happened this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was worth reporting on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, arranged by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

In the French Alps, at Mont Bego, there are tens of thousands of ancient rock carvings that are being slowly destroyed. These 36,000 drawings, which are about 4,000 years old, include images of cows with horns, fields, and gods and goddesses. The site was once a place for prayer and worship. However, as more tourists visit, the carvings are being damaged by graffiti and careless behavior.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, warns that if the damage continues, the drawings might not last another 50 years. He has seen tourists walking on the carvings, which wears them down, and some even take pieces home as souvenirs. When visitors can't take clear photos, they rub the drawings to make them more visible, which harms them. Some people even scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts disagree on how to protect the site. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, suggests making the mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing access only through guided tours. He believes this is necessary to prevent the site from being completely destroyed and to protect research work. However, Clottes thinks this approach is too extreme and would upset local residents. He emphasizes the importance of preserving the site, which is classified as a historic monument.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also opposes closing the site. He suggests allowing people to visit but acknowledges the challenge of preventing damage due to the site's large size. He mentions the possibility of charging an entrance fee to fund more guards, as there is no government funding available.

Annie Echassoux, a researcher, is concerned that easier access to the mountain, such as by hiring vehicles, will lead to more damage. She believes the area should be roped off and guided tours provided. She insists that financial constraints should not stop efforts to protect the site, as it is a historic area recognized by the Ministry of Culture. If no action is taken, future generations may lose these valuable drawings.

Title: Shopping with Children

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says it's very hard because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she buys them. But she also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed before they even leave the house. She tries not to take them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a shopping trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when ads make products look so appealing.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often have to say no to their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy products, so even if they can't directly tell children to ask their parents, the ads still have that effect.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse can be very stressful for parents. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and advertisements, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his son because they're unhealthy, even though he buys treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent because his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without their children's demands might attract more customers.

**Going up the wall**

In the past, climbers went to mountains to climb. Now, you can find challenging climbs anywhere, both indoors and outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham's National Indoor Arena, the crowd watches in awe. High above them, French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, and both events feature a key element - The Wall. This is possible because of new and fast-developing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were many good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, top climbers needed to stay fit all year. When cliffs were not usable, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing. These walls used bricks with special edges to hold onto. Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, was one of the first to build a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He set natural rock into concrete blocks for the wall. Many similar walls were built in sports halls during the 1970s, but they had design problems. These walls were only vertical, unlike natural cliffs that have overhangs and angled rocks. Once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like natural cliff features. These shapes could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have endless new holds to try.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. And they are right; acting is a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But choosing to be an actor is a personal decision, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy paths - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training, you will succeed. It's about luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new faces and talent, and acting can be exciting, glamorous, and sometimes very rewarding. People often ask me to explain what talent is. I think it's a mix of natural skill and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeeded, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they don't take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is an actor's biggest enemy. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Then, you get an audition, but even if you want the job, you might not get it. So, actors don't talk much about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing for roles and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, from the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It's up to you because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles currently available.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to book for anyone wondering, "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur cook to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, accompanies his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by explaining how and why ingredients behave in certain ways. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 fantastic recipes and explains why some dishes might fail, using basic food chemistry to make things clear. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's excellent at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For over 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to achieve perfection. To celebrate its centenary, the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook* presents 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While the recipes are classic, they remain fresh and have been updated to reduce calories. The book starts with basic kitchen procedures and continues with sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Fast food? Many think good food requires long hours in the kitchen, but Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This new book offers more than 200 enticing recipes from around the world, all ready in just 30 minutes. Written in his fun and engaging style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. If you doubt it, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

It's true - we're all getting taller

Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're becoming a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of poor diets from the past, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again, who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. Some tribes still live this way. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This limited diet has harmed our health and growth. Over time, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing, was actually a health problem, according to some experts. However, farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. 

Only recently have wealthier countries started to improve nutrition. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like those of our ancestors. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it brings challenges. While people are getting taller, things like bed lengths and legroom in planes and trains have not changed much. Clothes manufacturers also have to adjust their products. The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University suggests it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century.

However, scientists note that while individuals are getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller, even with good nutrition. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink even more. So, global warming could counteract the growth in human height.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was suddenly made redundant. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm happy not to be stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counselor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to get back to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left all our friends, but our friendships have survived the distance, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

Title: A Childhood Game Turns Into a Business Success

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are turning a childhood game into a successful business. In their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, they play an old game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family loved playing it on weekends and holidays. Even after moving to New Mexico, they continued to enjoy the game.

Three years ago, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was worn out, so he made a new one. It was so well-made that family and friends wanted their own. Curious about the game's appeal, the brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were skeptical, but once they tried it, they couldn't stop playing.

Dave researched the game's history and found it likely originated in India as a game called 'carroms.' It evolved into 'squails' in Britain and was brought to Canada by British immigrants. The French-Canadian version is called pichenotte.

Pichenotte is a skill-based game for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks,' which they flick across a board to score points. The goal is to flick a puck into a small hole for 20 points, with other rings worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game is fast, usually lasting just two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity, the brothers started making more boards and selling them at markets and fairs. The game became so popular that championships were organized, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. The boards sold quickly, leading the brothers to start a full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards so far. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. They sell for $595 on the brothers' website.

Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are optimistic. They hope their business will grow enough to replace their garage workshop with a luxury car. Until then, they enjoy playing the game that might make them rich.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. However, one man's careful planning and hard work, with constant support from his wife, transformed this land into the beautiful place you see today. 

During the construction of the village, many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Bulldozers and digging machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, carefully chosen to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to withstand all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. 

You will notice that all models are made to a constant scale, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses on modeling.

All the model buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can lead to hours of repair work. You can take photos from the paths, and dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To enhance your visit, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press them to see the models in action.

At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet the high standards of the rest of the village, as we are constantly updating and replacing them. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Sometimes pop stars pose for paparazzi, but this is not common. Usually, these photos harm public figures by showing their private moments on the front page. However, few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such issues. These photos rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a photo of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where privacy is expected, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It's shocking that the PCC didn't investigate on its own. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star didn't make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair attacks? 

At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public wouldn't support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it wouldn't be profitable to wait for celebrities to take secret photos. If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', which it could, there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC realistically monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there's the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret, which could come out if they complain. In this way, even the PCC might seem like an enemy.

A British comedian also suffered from the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor when his family was photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the photos again with a new story about his 'anger', claiming it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to college graduates starting their first job. In this article, we will talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job after just a few weeks. Instead, we focus on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for next? It depends on your long-term goals. Ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher positions, or switch to a different field. Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career. 

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned how an office works and improved her computer skills. But there was no room for growth, so she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I went from mostly typing and answering phones to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with various questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were born that way, but most will tell you it's a skill they learned because they needed to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.

A. Jenny
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I surprised myself by doing well. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B. Michaela
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought that's how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lack confidence, so I talk to myself to overcome those fears.

C. Lisa
People think I'm very confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. I had to learn to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that most of us get nervous in important situations, and we feel better when we talk to someone friendly. My mother once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves.' That's good advice. You gain confidence by facing things that scare you. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that scared again.

D. Barbara
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over the years. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am liked in the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have boosted my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's helpful to see you're achieving something real, rather than aiming too high and getting nothing.

E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary and often disagreed in meetings but was too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down a few notes, like a comfort blanket. Everyone feels a bit nervous about public speaking. The real secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them in the shade of the whispering pine trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest and most serious kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held up the kites, and a row of nervous competitors holding their kite lines waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites shot up into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each entered four different designs to be judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 'Flying kites isn't so hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I received five such invitations that day and decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large polished room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving my car inland towards Kuala Lumpur, into granite mountains covered with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A long, narrow boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and about a dozen bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, full of different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and thousands of living things moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was an amazing view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind, then lightning hit the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the many giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. No one stays a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were only being friendly. Kelantan might be best known for its kites, but I remember it more for its human kindness.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone shops, whether they like it or not. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits:

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I'm a shopping addict—I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and don't tell my husband the real price—I always say it cost less! The real price sounds too shocking.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really need to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather be doing something else.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and shop quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my girlfriends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper—I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want and never buy things immediately. I check other shops to find a better deal—it takes me a long time!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops don't interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I do it quickly and don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!
