Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University offers degrees just like any other university. However, you can continue working while you study. It also allows you to explore many different interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet a variety of people and make new friends. Your degree might also lead to new job opportunities. You don't need to attend lectures in person at the Open University. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Like other universities, there are exams to pass. If you want more information, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons to paint them. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery restaurant now has better and bigger services. With new kitchens, it offers a wide range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm, except Sundays. These tours show some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and cover important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Little Chefs

For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.'

Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to make food for themselves when they leave home.'

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. If there are more people, each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. If you are visiting with a group, please let the centre know before you come.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. The course costs £32.50, which includes all equipment.

One-day adventure course
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course is designed to introduce adults to outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You don’t need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. The course costs £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We also offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and are qualified to teach the activities. We make sure that all children only do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.

Stamp Collecting - A Hobby That Keeps Growing

Millions of people, young and old, enjoy stamp collecting because it's interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a hobby that can last a lifetime. It's easy to start because stamps are everywhere. You can get them from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world.

Once you get serious about collecting, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You have three options for receiving them: we can mail you a complete set on an envelope, send them in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or provide individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5, and there's a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, you get a Starter Pack at no extra cost. It includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also receive a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to add to your collection and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive the club magazine, full of competitions and quizzes, and opportunities to exchange stamps with members worldwide. Why not start an adventure that will bring you years of enjoyment? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun of stamp collecting. To join, just fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

**Write a Winning Story!**

You have a chance to win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and get your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write great stories. The judges, including novelist Mary Littlejohn, TV reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor Susan Hitchins, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. 

**Tips for Writing:**

- **Write About What You Know:** This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most writers followed this advice. Common topics were love, family, and friendship problems. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Write about everyday things in a new and surprising way.

- **Get Your Facts Right:** If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure you are correct. Only write about things you are sure about.

- **Hold the Reader's Attention:** Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A bad ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of an unusual ending.

- **Think About the Characters:** Make the people in your story feel real by using the right words. 

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. Include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and your story must not have been published or broadcast anywhere in the world. 

The entry fee is £5, which goes to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that his daughter received the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we don't have any copies of her books, we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to assist her work. During that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people involved in it were at risk. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices might apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from across Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower,' which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, the James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programs can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass can quickly grow back after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, who has always loved fashion, recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her creations and asked her to make clothes for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis, and they sold very well. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels very fortunate and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered great service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to reach the center, and buses to other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Be careful not to take buses with the blue sign "Express" on the front, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance, and one week's notice is required for departures. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am; lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm; dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, if you are studying or working late, you can request dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for heating food or the room) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a child, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in films and remains very popular with his many fans worldwide.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven more than 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking around. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered something to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin in northern Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm north coast through endless desert to the cooler Southern Ocean. It's often called the 'famous Ghan', but it's mostly known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan doesn't offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally meant to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. Completing a transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board, everyone seemed excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to get on. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I left the train at Alice Springs for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so we just walked around it and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train isn't very interesting, mostly flat land with cattle. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey ended, and while the train might not have met all the promises of the advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon got steep, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we weren't so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as climbing up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to slopes that are too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we just moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place because the builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. However, this new school is one of the first in our country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land for the school, although it meant losing some nice open space. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are huge—much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they need it for meetings and other events. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and large changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, one of the first things you notice is that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from all of us inside—the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed so well that it keeps all the heat inside—and the sound too. If we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders put it there because it's a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that you can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school building, there are still some parts to be added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we still have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**
Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**
As a special offer, you can choose any discounted books from our new members' book list, worth up to £6 in total (plus postage and packing). This way, you save money compared to the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen by our staff from our book list. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**
As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month to keep you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**
All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a fiction or reference book they think is worth buying—at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we do not hear from you.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this don't come every day. To become a member, just fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and actually enjoying it. As I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with his two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. After I explained, he gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, and everything inside was untouched. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most feared animals in the ocean. They are very good at hunting because they have excellent vision and can sense movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes them very dangerous to smaller sea animals, which they eat. While sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for researchers who need to study sharks, as it allows them to learn more about these interesting animals.'

I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started speaking English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. 

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once because I felt lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are really tough, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was so cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy.

Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.

The ICEHOTEL

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. But in winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people thought the cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and lots of wool socks. It's a good idea to wear shoes that are bigger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store for special deals, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). Normally, the store will be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for 24 hours straight on its first day. However, it had to close just 30 minutes after opening. A police officer at the scene said: 'We knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. People outside got upset because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly. Another issue was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the store, which blocked the road completely.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got inside, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

Membership  
The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations.  

Society Magazines  
We produce several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on this website.  

National Short Story Competition  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Society members do not pay an entry fee, while non-members pay £5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.  

Education  
For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and building their confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.  

The Writers' Cafe  
The Writers' Cafe is the Society's social center. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in the heart of London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.  

Becoming a Member  
We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a famous free-diver with four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on just one breath. In 2003, Tanya made history by diving 120 meters deep and returning to the surface without any help. She had gone deeper the year before but used a balloon to help her come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive at different depths to ensure her safety. 

Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of past accidents, but Tanya believes safety and training are most important. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, choosing fast walking instead.

When Tanya practices diving, she often travels and aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, resting every other day to avoid getting tired. Outside of training, she makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research and making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools, which she says is like living her childhood dreams. Tanya is well-known in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. Now in her thirties, she plans to keep breaking her own records and doesn't intend to retire soon, as she only started free-diving at twenty-five.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people in the cinema industry thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors came up with some original new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson, a new TV star, shares her experience of acting in her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. Before this, I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

The outdoor filming began a week after university started, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on my essays. I didn't tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was amazing. It was a fantastic experience, and I feel very lucky. 

After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I don't come from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I wasn't sure what to do next. Since then, I've acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a global company that is growing quickly around the world. Over the years, I have learned a lot. Many of these lessons are in this book because I believe our company has valuable ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel like part of a family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world and makes them known. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can host 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and toilet. The ship is air-conditioned and includes a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. Upon arrival, your guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** Continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. You can enjoy local food and drinks at dinner.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego. Visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum, which was once a palace and now has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the Douro River Valley to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

**Day 7:** Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river back to Oporto. Spend the night on the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than 300 types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food - it can also be used for sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. The city has a growing student population and is a successful commercial center, being the largest center for insurance services outside London. Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's modern attractions is a shopping center called 'The Castle Mall.' For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the project. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has managed to combine the best of the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival happened in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, there were only about twelve hot-air balloons, and they took off from a parking lot in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current location outside the city.

What to See

The balloon pilots stay in contact with each other by radio and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking amazing photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am when the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to take off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, and some are shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you are not using a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular places for tourists to visit. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality for just £6.99 quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. For example, Jane Harris's Those Nails should not be read right after eating because it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! There is excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are also parts of novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an outstanding collection, and I am excited to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at ages three and four, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, happening once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes. It is important for parents to be actively involved in the lessons. From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and their music reading skills. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" follows their previous CD, "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it's clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets should not worry, as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco

San Francisco is on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote the most famous diary in English. His diary gives a detailed and interesting look at everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys talks about important events of the time, like a disease outbreak, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his flaws - he often fell asleep in church or admired pretty girls. He describes his home life, such as arguments with his wife and how they made up, and his worries about her health. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, people didn't care much if shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I decided to help more women get into running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident to start running. I started a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers behaved. They often complain that not many women participate in the sport, but they also don't provide separate changing rooms for women. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were of different ages and fitness levels. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did think about it, they imagined it as hard and painful training. They didn't think about running while chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like along a river. At first, they could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned from other runners about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to support women's running, and I have enjoyed watching their progress almost as much as they have.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built and expanded. One of these towns was Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, boats could bring essential supplies to these towns, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making travel impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They delivered mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to cross Alaska. Along the way, they stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat, and feed their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main way to travel. However, the dogs had one last important role in 1925 when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a dependable guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to move forward, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit every year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so it's not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, the hotel can also provide suitable outdoor clothing. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one minded that I was a girl, but then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed she was very fast. "He talked to me about athletics, but I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was really hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could succeed in athletics and help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had refused before because she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot." Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year living happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You need to wear special shoe covers to protect the glass from scratches. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the sky.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest and extend to areas just a few hundred miles from the center in the south. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start in Vancouver, which is one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still a great adventure. You sleep on the train, which is exciting, but you pass through some of the most beautiful scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the early zoos, animals were often trained to perform tricks for visitors. This is no longer the case, as zoos now focus on letting people see animals in their natural behavior. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters of zoos say they allow us to learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which wouldn't be possible otherwise. On the other hand, critics argue that it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half do. But anyone who is eager to play comes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music, but you also feel like you're part of its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get anywhere with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a network of underground channels, built in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. Places like this, which are usually dry but get water this way, are called oases. If you travel further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. Gareth has two older brothers who work in banking and computers. However, Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth decided to join the circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three."

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath thought about finding full-time jobs in a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. During the summer, they travel with the circus, and in the winter, they go back home. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

"It wasn't easy," says Kath. "We had a lot to plan and organize. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house behind. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

People often ask about Gareth's education. Gareth says, "From the start, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as my classmates at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind in my studies."

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a hard decision, but it was the only way for Gareth to learn about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? He says, "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. Our members gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the stories accepted by these media on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers across the country where young people can meet and work on projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide.

Our agency started in 1994, originally called 'Young News.' Since then, over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie, a former member, says: "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article on young people's views on hip hop music. I was impressed by the young journalists and the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I joined the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and stayed until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I imagined. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online."

Get involved at every level

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who teach new members basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff during these trips.

Eight-eighteen News offers training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members is in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

**Flight Overview**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back in a Boeing 747. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, you can transfer your deposit if the date changes.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning. During the flight, experts who have lived in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you the view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will switch to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, you can move around the plane to enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see the sights from both sides of the plane.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite cloud images and chooses the route with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you would need to take a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can take photos. We also offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly as you go over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it. Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow twice your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law but ended up going to art school instead. He found traditional drawing classes hard but continued to paint. In his late twenties, he received a grant from the Italian government to study art. This experience made him interested in early Italian artists, which influenced some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. To do this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he says he never knows exactly how the painting will turn out. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound simple, saying, 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make drawings before starting a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their pictures while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he doesn't care about following any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn't like the idea because of the noise. Ben said, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. "Okay," we said, "but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, our house is filled with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. I must admit that, even though their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical skill—after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people.

Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain—Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives students important life experiences outside the classroom, along with preparing them for exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the morning and do useful activities in the afternoon, like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body. Students come from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are high, at £20,000 for two years, many students receive financial help. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can attend only because they get government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education with methods that truly work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent salary, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me mentally. I felt stuck and unhappy in my job. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy and full of hope. I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often think I'm a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am grateful for this chance to study because I know a qualification is important for getting a fulfilling job, which matters a lot to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. There are also typical student benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age has been a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he created the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next one start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez
