Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs £200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and I didn't even take a toothbrush. I'm usually a clean person, but there's no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only bring enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the climb, and people often ask her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science TV program. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was really good; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

CANADA GEESE

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed there. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn." Bill had a small plane, so he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to return. They didn't come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without his help!

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly doubled the £500. At first, her parents didn't want her to spend time making jam; they thought she should study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther didn't listen and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew a lot, and her parents were very happy with her success. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she had to hire people to help her.

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has some work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you invite Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline'

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they keep cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to prevent them from getting too hot.

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the weather was too warm, so people weren't interested in buying sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which everyone loved because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began.

Initially, Jenny made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are made by machines. There are six different colors, five sizes for all ages, and special socks for walkers, athletes, and skiers. Jenny is busiest during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

28 Long Road Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,

I arrived here three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.

Best wishes,  
Maria

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave a door or window open by mistake. He explained that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home. However, he said that winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark, making it hard to see them. Also, many houses are empty then because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to watch each other's houses when people are not home and to call the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This advice is free.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I want to say thank you for letting me stay at your lovely home for two nights. It was great to see you both again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you like them. I really enjoy using my new camera. Next week, I am going to visit my sister in New York. I plan to take many photos there as well. It's been a long time since I last saw my sister.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming, people searched forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, about 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started growing their own food. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, and their villages gradually grew larger. Some villagers could focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and some people didn't have enough to eat. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it can travel thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.'

Nicola Peet started working after finishing school at eighteen. She went to college and then got a job at a local airport. After nine months, she worked for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she became a manager. Here’s what she says about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach flight attendants and help them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. The first thing I do at work is check flight times on my computer, and then I talk to some of the flight attendants. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat and sleep! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back in my home country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love,  
Sophie

Dear Sir,  
  
I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name written on the outside. Have you found this bag?  
  
Yours faithfully,  
Mary Johnson  
  
Dear Ms. Johnson,  
  
I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day.  
  
Yours sincerely,  
J. Wilson

People 

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make a computer game, and now it's ready to use. It's a game with speaking and pictures. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there's a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be sold worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Title: How Do the Irish Pop-Group 'Boyzone' Live a Healthy Life?

Getting enough sleep is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard for me to sleep because I keep thinking about the music. 

Exercise is also important. Before my car accident, I used to spend two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports center. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups every day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke, and I try to eat healthy food. I also drink a lot of water because it's good for health. I aim for about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that.

It's important not to work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. It's healthy to relax and do nothing sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since my doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat a lot of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy eating burgers occasionally!

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the number of films made in the USA, making Bollywood the largest film industry in the world. Watching films is the favorite free-time activity for most Indians, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films usually tell romantic love stories and always include singing and dancing. These films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make, while a Hollywood film usually costs at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is different; he is considered one of India's greatest actors and has starred in more than 140 films over nearly 40 years.

Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. However, for the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, is about to start college here, so we will stay for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss the book I just wrote. Most writers don't enjoy traveling around to promote their books, but I don't mind it. I like visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the U.S. when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because Schnauzers are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and great with young children.

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two large towns. 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite class today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is the first book by David Reilly. David started writing after teaching English for several years. The story is about Maha, a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

Hard Work  
This exciting story is the twentieth book by Joanna Jones. It is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long and hard making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day, a man dressed in all black buys the most beautiful table in their shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. The story is about Tina, a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. But one day, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina choose to do?

Horse racing has been an important sport throughout history. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses were brought to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, in the early 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing at once. Today, horse racing is very popular in the USA, second only to baseball, and is also enjoyed in many other countries.

Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job. He travels around the world to make TV shows. "People are friendly everywhere I go, and when I return home, I think about all the amazing experiences I had in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still some trips he wants to take. "I'd love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he adds. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed for filming. Nick doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to bring some books. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick returns, she enjoys hearing all his travel stories. However, there can be challenges. Once, when Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he found out that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so relieved when I heard she was better," he says.

Parrots

You might have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups. Because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but all of them have strong beaks and feet. They use these for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds and can be taught to talk easily. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on lots of clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he made the right choice.'

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England, where he cuts the grass and waters the flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. This is because John, who is 35 years old, is currently the top singer in Japan. A few months ago, he went to Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station to request his songs again. In Japan, John uses the stage name Jon Otis, but he plans to continue working in the park in England. He is not sure how much money he will make from his music yet. "I need to keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have bills to pay!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This won't change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Memo To: All staff  
Subject: Holidays  
From: D Brown  
Date: 22.2.02  

I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, could you provide two date options? Please give me your response by the end of the month. Thank you.  
D Brown  

---

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green  
Date: 23.2.02  

Could I take two weeks' holiday in July? I would prefer the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I take three extra days off in the first week of December?  
John

Line Dancing

In Britain, many people have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. You can find clubs and classes for this activity in almost every town. According to Fiona Lever, a line dancing teacher, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups, which makes it a great way to meet new friends. In Fiona's classes, both young and old people participate. Boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing.

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open areas of Africa, while the others live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat only grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born, after being inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

The History of the London Police

Today, you can see policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London didn't have any policemen. A few old men used to watch over the city streets at night, but they didn't earn much money. About 300 years ago, London started to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people preferred to stay at home.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began paying a group of people to catch thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown a lot and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3000 officers. Most of them worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are paid quite well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It gets very cold at night, so make sure to bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so consider booking your hotel now!

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy," he says. "First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then, you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

Subject: Bad Week

Hi Anna,

I'm having a tough week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us. Then, my friend Jeff from Australia called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news to share! Please write back today if you can.

Greg

Madame Tussaud's

A very popular tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and started a museum for them in Paris. Marie helped her uncle with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While there, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her wax figures are still on display today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have now. Later, as bicycles became less expensive, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to go to work and for leisure activities. Today, cars are used more than bicycles because they are much faster and you stay dry when it rains. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers and it's hard to find parking spaces.

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of big white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started painting on its card. The trainers helped by giving them new brushes with paint and taking the old ones away. Slowly, the elephants followed their trainers' instructions and drew pictures. I was amazed! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the trainers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Big Cats

There are many types of cats, and they are different in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats. They can be up to 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often lie in it to cool down when it's hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. Several lions work together to hunt for food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. All cats need good eyesight because they hunt smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I'm sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sad to leave the English class. You are a great teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and let me know when you are free and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm happy because I got a new job in the city center last month. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it's very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me wearing my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction when running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers per hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the size of chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson from Britain began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now, at 23, she has won many snowboarding competitions. We talked to her last week at a competition in Switzerland and asked why she started snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It's quick to learn, and you can become really good in just a few months." 

We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because they are so beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding without competing, is my favorite thing in the world."

We also asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet, because at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,

I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please give me a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel, so I would like to know if there is a car park available. I expect to arrive at around 10:30 p.m. Could you tell me what time the restaurant closes in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive.

Thank you for your assistance.

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is considered the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro make it to the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through the water at speeds of over 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very polluted, which caused many fish and insects to die, leaving otters with nothing to eat. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write to me and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family, and I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Tom

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return home to Greece. I really like London. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I will write to you again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I am visiting your country next month with two friends. We are not sure where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the center. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and pop concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. But the building is attractive from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This interesting building looks like a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I've grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have much money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large drawing of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one really knows when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 meters and possibly the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always stayed cheerful, and people in her hometown admire her for that. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a very long road race. She won with an excellent time, the fastest of the year for any British woman runner. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop competing after injuring his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it's not enjoyable for Mike when Gail overtakes him, and he can't keep up. Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. But she always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. By ten, he wanted to write music and soon began his first song.

Oleg Gagarin was the youngest of five children. At four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. When he was six, he started piano lessons with a teacher in his city. Oleg quickly began winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia.

Josef Heptmann's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England. Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music someday.

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, 13 years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office and in the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me if she doesn't like something," Bill says. His ten grandchildren, who don't live nearby, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading. 

Bill writes about life in his village and nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, "The Sheepdog," which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always liked animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." Last year, "The Sheepdog" was turned into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film," he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 19th century. It showed a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards started to have pictures of news events from that week, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. We don't know exactly why they became extinct. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs came in many different shapes and sizes. There were over 5000 types. Some were very small, while others were huge. The biggest dinosaurs were larger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex wasn't as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because of its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. But not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which is from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat anything they can catch, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the air. Then, 120 years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first airplane with an engine and flew it. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed a lot. In the 1950s, they became much faster because of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, so a trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round, there was no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen loved going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. All the actors at that time were men. The visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some people even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or just learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water there is very warm, and I love swimming. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
